DOC.HEAD: Ethiopia's President Vows Fight to End Defending Port
DOC.TEXT: President Mengistu Haile Mariam pledged a ``fight to the bitter end'' to defend the northern Red Sea port of Massawa now under attack by Eritrean rebels. He said in a broadcast to armed forces and police on Saturday night that losing Massawa would lead to the fall of the 2nd Army and secession of Eritrea, Ethiopia's northernmost province. ``The fall of the 2nd Army would be a heavy blow to the Ethiopian armed forces, endanger the unity and territorial integrity of the nation and facilitate the secession of Eritrea,'' the Marxist president said. It was his first comment on the fighting, which began Feb. 8 with the first offensive in more than a year by the Eritrean People's Liberation Front. The Eritreans claimed the capture of Massawa two days later, one of Ethiopia's two ports and gateway to trade involving Eritrea and its southern neighbor, Tigre. The rebels said they killed or captured about 12,600 soldiers and sank or captured nearly half the Ethiopian navy fleet of two frigates and 12 patrol craft, as listed by the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies. The Eritreans also said they controlled the 40-mile-long road from Massawa to Eritrea's capital, Asmara. Mengistu did not directly deny the rebel claim they had captured Massawa. He appeared to rule out any negotiations with the Eritrean rebels, however. ``The battle between us and the EPLF will be final and decisive,'' Mengistu said, using the acronym for the rebel group's name. ``We will either win the battle, which has been declared against us, and destroy a coordinated conspiracy against the nation, or a new group will emerge in the region which would opt for a peaceful solution to the crisis.'' The latest fighting halted relief operations. Mengistu said most of the 90,000 tons of emergency food at the port was destroyed by artillery fire. It was part of 1.1 million tons of emergency food the United Nations hoped to deliver through Massawa in the next few months to feed an estimated 4 million people threatened with famine, mostly in Eritrea and Tigre. Mengistu made no reference to government troop casualties or Massawa's 19,400 civilian population. The Ethiopian News Agency said Thursday civilians had been caught in ``ferocious house-to-house fighting.'' It said the port was bombarded from sea and land. On Saturday, the Eritreans claimed in a clandestine broadcast the Ethiopian air force had ``intermittently'' bombed Massawa since the fighting began. The rebels alleged the air force also dropped chemical bombs, killing civilians. Since fighting began, independent verficiation of rival claims has not been possible. Both sides, however, normally report only victories and each other's alleged atrocities. The Eritreans took up arms in 1962 to press for Eritrea's independence. Peace talks failed late last year.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders of Black Fraternities, Sororities Call For End to Hazing
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of eight national black fraternities and sororities announced an agreement Saturday to eliminate hazing by banning the pledging process. ``We have been greatly concerned about the hazards of hazing,'' said Janet Ballard, national president of Alpha Kappa Alpha, the nation's oldest black sorority. ``We came together here to seek means of membership intake which would safeguard our potential members, honor our traditions and maintain our organizational integrity.'' Also represented were Omega Psi Phi, Alpha Phi Alpha, Kappa Alpha Psi and Phi Beta Sigma fraternities, and Delta Sigma Theta, Sigma Gamma Rho and Zeta Phi Beta sororities. The groups have some 800,000 members. The groups passed a resolution declaring that each organization should develop its own initiation process limited to ceremonial rituals. The leaders said the resolution stemmed from their concern about excesses of hazing at some colleges in recent years that led to serious injuries. They said the new regulations would take effect as soon as they could be adopted by the organizations at national conventions this summer.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Acquits Christian Scientist Parents in Death of Child
DOC.TEXT: A Christian Scientist couple who tried to heal their ailing 15-month-old child through prayers have been acquitted on charges of involuntary manslaughter and child endangerment. Los Angeles County Superior Court Judge Robert Thomas ruled Friday that there was insufficient evidence to convict Eliot and Lise Glaser on the charges filed in the death of their son, Seth. The toddler died March 28, 1984 of meningitis following a two-day illness. Under state law, parents are required to provide basic necessities for their children, including food, clothing and medical care. A 1976 law sponsored by the Christian Science Church, however, exempts parents who treat children through prayer alone. The Glasers had sought protection from prosecution under that provision, arguing they had taken their child to a Christian Science healer. The issue was appealed to the California Supreme Court, which ruled that the exemption applies only to the felony charge of failure to provide basic necessities, and didn't offer immunity from prosecution on other charges. ``If Christian Scientists or any other religion eschews medical treatment in favor of prayer after their child exhibits symptoms that are critical to their health, they have a legal obligation to take that person to a physician,'' said the prosecutor, Deputy District Attorney David Wells. Following the appeal, both sides in the case agreed to let Thomas decide the Glasers' fate based on the transcripts of their 1985 preliminary hearing. The court record included the Glasers' version of what happened, as well as the testimony of two doctors who said the child could have been saved if his parents had brought him to a hospital. The court's decision turned on evidence that the child showed brief bursts of recovery during predominant periods of high fever, vomiting and discoloration, Wells said. The judge ruled that the periodic points of promise raised in his mind a reasonable doubt as to whether the religious healing was a wanton and grossly negligent act, Wells said.

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette Maker Confirms Effort to Market Dakotas
DOC.NOTE: EDs: adds 5 grafs quotes from young women
DOC.TEXT: R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. confirmed Saturday it plans to test market a new cigarette named Dakota but said the campaign would be aimed at adults who are currently smokers of Marlboros. ``It is intended to appeal to that large group of adults, both male and female, who are currently smoking Marlboro, the largest selling brand,'' said James W. Johnston, chairman and chief executive officer. The Washington Post reported in Saturday editions that a proposed marketing plan prepared for Reynolds by Promotional Marketing Inc. suggests Dakota be positioned to replace Marlboro as the brand of choice among female smokers with limited educations and between the ages of 18 and 24. Secretary of Health and Human Services Louis W. Sullivan, reacting to the report, said in a statement: ``Smoking is increasingly becoming concentrated among Americans with lower incomes and less education and this is simply wrong. ``It is especially reprehensible to lure young people into smoking and potential lifelong nicotine addiction. And the risk that smoking specifically poses for women adds yet another tawdry dimension to any cigarette marketing effort which may be aimed at younger women.'' He noted that lung cancer has overtaken breast cancer as the ``number one cause of death among women'' and said smoking poses special risks for pregnant women. Women who are 18 to 20 years old represent the only group of Americans whose rate of smoking continues to increase. Sullivan said he would present more detail about smoking problems at a hearing Tuesday before the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. The Post said the marketing plan proposed for Dakota, set for a test in Houston in April, targets women whose favorite pastimes include ``cruising,'' ``partying'' and attending hot rod shows and tractor pulls with their boy friends. It said documents it obtained showed the marketing plan is aimed at young white women with no education beyond high school who are described as ``virile females.'' The proposed campaign, called ``Project V.F.,'' for virile female, described the type of woman targeted as one who watches ``Roseanne'' and evening soap operas on television and who hopes to get married in her early 20s and spend her free time ``with her boyfriend doing whatever he is doing,'' according to the report. The Post said it was not clear whether R.J. Reynolds has adopted the marketing strategy proposed to it by Promotional Marketing Inc. Johnston said in a statement released by Reynolds that ``the Dakota marketing plan is focused on current adult Marlboro smokers _ nothing more, nothing less.'' ``The marketing plans for Dakota represent an implementation of Reynolds' objective or regaining market share lost over the past several years to our competitors,'' he said. ``This focus on competitive brands is no different than that of every other cigarette company or indeed any other consumer product company. Different products are designed to appeal to different categories of consumers,'' he said. ``Dakota is no different.'' Meanwhile, Kathleen Wiebers, executive director of the South Dakota Lung Association, noted that the state has the fifth-lowest smoking rate in the nation at 21.1 percent of the adult population, according to the federal Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report. ``That means that 80 percent of South Dakotans are non-smokers and we're pretty proud of that,'' Wiebers said. Reacting to the reported marketing plan for Dakota, she said: ``It's very upsetting that a tobacco company would think today's women are that naive. How dumb do they think we are?'' Valerie Lawruklvich, a bartender at Shooter's in Eugene, Oregon, said the Dakota name had a certain appeal, calling it a ``cool breezish type thing.'' But she said getting her to change brands probably would require more than just a name. ``At a discounted price to start with,'' she said, ``You know `buy one pack get another one free.' Something like that. T-shirt giveaways are a big item. I've bought certain cigarettes just for the T-shirt this previous year. You know, if they had like a really neat packaging type thing. A catchy name would also help.'' Donna Allgood, interviewed by telephone at the Whiskey Junction bar in Minneapolis, Minn., said: ``I don't think Dakota is a real good name, for a woman's cigarette at least. Personally speaking, I think when you start with a `D' word, that `duh', that's too harsh. It should be something softer.'' At the American Legion Hall in Marysville, Tenn., Sherrie Meisamer told a telephone interviewer she thinks the market campaign as it was related to her was ``very disgusting.'' ``They're trying to introduce younger age groups into the smoking sensation,'' she said. ``I don't think that's quite right myself. They're (young people) automatically going to buy because they'll put on a big display for it. I'm a smoker, I have been for several years. I don't take it as a personal affront, but I don't think it's very agreeable that they should try to overdramatize the younger crowd.''

DOC.HEAD: Bombs Explode in 2 Atlanta-Area Grocery Stores; Calls Prompted Evacuations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS in 3 grafs with authorities saying main explosives in bombs did not go off; pick up 3rd graf, `Callers also ...'
DOC.TEXT: Small explosions hit two grocery stores in this Atlanta suburb Saturday afternoon, shortly after stores were evacuated because of telephoned bomb threats. Authorities said the main explosives in the bombs did not detonate. No injuries were reported. ``The fuse train is all that detonated, so the effect of the bombs was really only that of a firecracker,'' FBI spokesman Pat Johnson said. ``It didn't do much damage except to its packaging.'' Callers also threatened bombings at two additional grocery stores and a fast-food outlet, police said. Investigators didn't believe the bombs were related to a series of mail bombs in the South in December that killed a federal judge and a lawyer, said Police Chief Jerry King. Agents from the FBI and the federal bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms were helping in the investigation. Police dispatcher Jill Moore said a caller telephoned a Cub Foods and a Kroger to say bombs would explode between 1:30 and 2 p.m. Two other grocery stores also reported threats, Ms. Moore said, a Big Star and a Winn-Dixie. Workers at a Kentucky Fried Chicken outlet also reported receiving a similar threat Saturday, King said. About 1,200 people were evacuated from the four stores because of the threats, officials said. Witnesses at the Kroger market said they were about 50 yards from the glass store front when the bomb exploded but didn't hear anything. ``We did not hear it, not at all,'' said Rhonda Bartlett, Kroger perishables manager. Police Cpl. William Anastasnio, who was in the Kroger when the bomb exploded, described it as sounding like a shotgun. The bomb was inside a cardboard display in an aisle, King said.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Avalanche Kills 21
DOC.TEXT: An avalanche in western Iran killed at least 21 people and left 31 others missing, the official news agency reported Sunday. The Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Cyprus, said the avalanche occurred Friday afternoon in the Zankl Doul mountains near Sar Dasht close to the Iraqi border. It quoted an unidentified local official as saying 79 local villagers trapped by the avalanche were rescued, and searchers continued looking for 31 other people. The agency provided no further details.

DOC.HEAD: Mudslides, Power Outages in California; Flooding in South
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `In Southern ...,' to UPDATE with road reopened; pick up 5th graf, `The storm ...'. SUBS 14th graf, `More than 80 ...,' to UPDATE with Interstate 80 reopened; pick up 15th graf, `More than 20,000 ...'
DOC.TEXT: Wind and rain triggered mudslides in California, doused crews cleaning up the Huntington Beach oil spill and left thousands without power Saturday, while floods in the South killed five people and drove hundreds from their homes. President Bush declared six central Alabama counties a disaster area late Saturday. Rivers across the state swelled out of their banks, covering farmland and threatening some homes, after two days of torrential rain that was blamed for one drowning death. Thunderstorms that dumped up to a foot of rain in parts of northern Georgia caused flooding that left two dead and forced evacuations of more than 1,000. In Mississippi, floods killed a young brother and sister and forced at least 300 people from their homes. In Southern California, tons of mud and large rocks rolled onto Malibu Canyon Road, forcing the Highway Patrol to close the narrow, twisting road from the ocean to the Ventura Freeway. The highway reopened 12 hours later, said Sgt. Frank Kasko of Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department. The storm knocked out power for for about 10,000 customers in sections of Los Angeles, said Ed Freudenberg, a Department of Water and Power spokesman. In Huntington Beach, some 470 workers in yellow rain slickers and white hard hats spent 12-hour shifts in the rain cleaning up oil washed ashore from the Feb. 7 spill from the tanker American Trader. Wind and waves knocked apart a boom blocking Newport Harbor, and boat operators struggled in rough seas to install temporary booms, said Sgt. Andy Gonis of the Newport Beach Police Department. But officials said the storm did offer some benefits. ``We're thinking the rain might actually help by uncovering some of the oil and tar balls that might be under the sand,'' said Tony Kozlowski, spokesman for British Petroleum, which had chartered the American Trader. Northern Californians got pelted by rain, snow and hail Saturday as an arctic storm knocked out power to about 200,000 homes. ``I'm hoping they have blankets, wood-burning stoves, stuff like that,'' Pacific Gas and Electric Co. spokesman Lyle LaFaver said about the customers who found themselves without gas or electricity after heavy winds and snows damaged the utility's transmission system. Power had been knocked out for about 100,000 Northern Californians when the storm first blasted through the region on Friday. LaFaver said Butte, El Dorado, Placer and Nevada counties remained hard-hit on Saturday, and 25,000 could still be without service on Sunday. Most of the communities have between two and three feet of snow. Many also lost telephone service because of the storm. Blizzard conditions kept more than 80 miles of Interstate 80 shut between Applegate and the Nevada state line for much of Saturday, the Highway Patrol reported. The highway reopened Saturday night. More than 20,000 electric customers in central Illinois remained without service Saturday as two utilities had extra crews working to restore power. More than 57,000 customers suffered outages when a midweek storm blanketed much of nothern and central Illinois with snow and ice. In the usually mild, drizzly Seattle area, the snow that arrived Friday night tapered off by midday Saturday, giving way to clear skies and bright sunshine. Snow lingered in southwest Washington and a freeze warning was issued for northwest Washington as arctic air was expected to pour south out of British Columbia. The Olympia area, recovering from a Wednesday night storm, received an additional 10 inches early Saturday, while Spokane had 5 inches. At Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, crews worked all night to keep the main runway open and only a few flights were delayed, said airport supervisor Lynette McNamara. ``The airport is in good condition. It's getting here (from other airports affected by bad weather) that seems to be the problem,'' she said. Water levels began dropping in two Georgia towns hard-hit by floods, but weather forecasters warned of more flooding through Sunday as rivers crest. More rain was expected in some areas. Police in the Atlanta suburb of Smyrna on Saturday found the body of Lawrence DeVoe, 69, in a car in the flooded driveway of the Oakdale Moose Lodge. Joe Crowe, 43, drowned Friday in Trion after he was swept away by flood waters when his car stalled. The flooding followed thunderstorms that dumped up to 12 inches of rain in some parts of north Georgia, pushing rivers and creeks over their banks. About 550 people fled their homes in Fannin County after the Toccoa River was over its banks. In Trion, authorities said as many as 1,000 people evacuated after 10 inches of rain fell in about 15 hours, pushing the Chattooga River out of its banks and over a dam. Extensive flooding of Alabama's lowlands was reported all along the Coosa, Black Warrior and Tallapoosa rivers. Authorities in Cherokee County said Mary E. Stallings, 76, was killed trying to walk across a swollen stream that blocked the road. A spokesman for Gov. Hunt, Terry Abbott, said Saturday that President Bush had declared a federal disaster area in central Alabama that included Bibb, Greene, Russell, Shelby, Talladega and Tuscaloosa counties. Carl Suchocki, a spokesman for the Federal Emergency Management Agency, said the declaration made individuals eligible for federal assistance for damages from several violent storms that began Feb. 3. In Mississippi, a 7-year-old girl and her 4-year-old brother died after the vehicle they were riding in with their grandmother and mother got stuck in a flood along the Bogue Chitto River on Friday night. Katrina Hughes had been holding her grandmother's hand but currents swept her away and she drowned, Pike County Coroner Bennie Hunt said. Hunt said Kenneth Ray Hughes died Saturday morning of hypothermia.

DOC.HEAD: Missing Former Gubernatorial Aide Found
DOC.TEXT: A top aide to former Gov. Edmund G. ``Jerry'' Brown who disappeared the day the FBI disclosed he admitted laundering cash was found in a Las Vegas hotel, apparently suffering a drug overdose, police said. Richard T. Silberman, 60, was in serious but stable condition at University Medical Center of Southern Nevada, hospital spokesman Dale Pugh said. San Diego police detectives working with Las Vegas police found Silberman at about 5:30 p.m. Saturday at the Las Vegas Hilton, where he had registered under his own name, San Diego police Sgt. Jim Clear said. Pugh declined to say why Silberman was hospitalized, but Clear said he apparently was suffering a drug overdose. Silberman's wife, county Supervisor Susan Golding, notified authorities Friday that her husband was missing after he failed to return home Thursday night. Silberman _ chief of staff to Brown, who was governor from 1975 to 1982 _ faces trial along with reputed San Diego mobster Chris Petti and three others on charges they laundered money that an FBI undercover agent presented to them as cocaine trafficking profits. Silberman was arrested April 7, 1989, as he left a hotel room where he had talked with the undercover agent. The conversation was videotaped. The arrest came at the end of a 2{-year undercover operation that included the extensive use of wiretaps and other eavesdropping devices. Silberman has been free on a $500,000 surety bond that required him to stay in California. He disappeared the day the FBI released a report saying he admitted accepting $100,000 in one transaction and $200,000 in a second from the undercover agent and directed four others to launder it. The report said Silberman told FBI agents he knew the deals were ``stupid,'' but he wanted the money to help save his troubled gold-mining company, Yuba Natural Resources Inc. The report was made public after a federal appellate court turned down requests by Silberman's lawyers to keep it secret.

DOC.HEAD: News Media: Conservatives to Hold Majority
DOC.TEXT: Major news media declared that the governing conservative party would hold its majority in the lower house of Parliament, based on computer projections from Sunday's national election. If final returns bore out the projections, issued less then four hours after the polls closed, the Liberal Democratic Party could claim it had been pardoned for a widespread influence-buying scandal that cut into its popularity and played a part in two prime ministers resigning last year. Kyodo News Service and NHK, the public-supported Japan Broadcasting Corp., said their computer projections showed the governing party keeping its majority. Liberal Democratic leaders also declared they believed the party would hold its majority, though final official returns were not expected until Monday afternoon. Party Secretary-General Ichiro Ozawa told reporters he believed the party would hold at least a bare majority of 257 seats in the 512-seat lower house, which has power to name the prime minister and pass the budget without assent of the upper house. Another party official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he was confident of reaching 265 seats, and hoped for 270 to give a vote of confidence to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and enough power to deal with the opposition, which controls the upper house. The party currently holds 295 seats. ``I was concerned that the party would barely win a majority, and internal struggle would hinder the party's ability to bargain with the opposition,'' the official said. Early unofficial returns showed the Liberal Democrats, who have held power since 1955 when the party was formed, losing some of their seats but holding a lead over the combined opposition. Ozawa said it was clear that four of the party's incumbents had lost in farm constituencies in northern Japan. ``Of course we wanted to defend our dominance in those constituencies, but under the severe situation we have to accept defeats,'' the No. 2 party figure told reporters at party election headquarters. About 71 percent of the 90.5 million eligible voters _ a high turnout identical to that in the 1986 election _ cast ballots at more than 50,000 polling stations nationwide. Forecasts by NHK, based on early partial counts, said the governing Liberal Democrats held 185 seats and the combined opposition 147 shortly after 10 p.m., four hours after the polls closed. Kaifu, head of the Liberal Democrats, and Socialist Chairwoman Takako Doi, who could become Japan's first woman prime minister if the opposition scores an upset victory, each said they believed their sides would win.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 3 Dead, 10 Injured In Maryland Motel Explosion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with two people unaccounted-for, quotes from witnesses, hotel management, other detail. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Hawbacker said...'. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: An explosion apparently caused by a gas leak tore through a motel Sunday morning, setting off a fire and killing at least three people, authorities said. The victims of the 5:30 a.m. blast at the Super 8 Motel were not immediately identified. Ten other people were injured, none seriously, authorities said. ``The whole front of the building had been blown out and was engulfed in flames,'' said Fire Chief Gary Hawbaker. ``We had debris blown out onto the highway. It was quite a powerful explosion.'' The motel is three stories tall. He said firefighters were searching for two people who were not accounted for. Part of the problem of checking on all the guests was that some of the motel's records were burned, he said. Some guests reported smelling gas before the explosion. ``I had just gotten up to go to the bathroom and had come back and my wife said, `Don't you smell the gas?''' said Neal Woodrick, 60, of Trenton, N.J. ``And then it happened.'' ``It sounded just like a bomb had gone off _ boom,'' said his wife, Joan Woodrick, 58. She said guests evacuated the motel in a ``very orderly'' manner. Ron Peterson, regional manager for Super 8 Management Inc., said motel employees were working with the Red Cross ``to get the people and their luggage straightened out.'' ``There is going to be a lot of turmoil here until we can get this situation turned around,'' he said. Hawbaker said the explosion was unrelated to a bomb blast last December that injured Washington County Circuit Judge John P. Corderman. ``I feel very comfortable ruling out bombs,'' Hawbaker said. ``Initial reports indicate that it was some kind of a gas leak.'' A dispatcher at the Washington County Fire and Rescue Service said at least 10 people were taken Washington County Hospital for treatment of what were described as minor injuries. Officials with the Maryland state fire marshal's office and four fire companies were on the scene. Traffic was diverted away from the area. Hagerstown is in western Maryland about 65 miles northwest of Baltimore.

DOC.HEAD: 28 Killed in Plane Crash in Zambia
DOC.TEXT: A Zambian air force transport plane crashed while trying to land at Lusaka's international airport, killing all 28 people aboard, the government said Sunday. Defense Secretary Alex Shapi said the Canadian-built Buffalo transporter was on a routine flight from Mbala in northern Zambia late Saturday when it crashed, scattering wreckage over a wide area near the airport. The dead were identified only as 14 air force personnel, 11 civilians, one army officer and two national service staff. Shapi refused to speculate on the cause of the crash, saying an investigation would be conducted. Military planes routinely use the civil airport in Zambia.

DOC.HEAD: Nineteen People Killed in Two Bus Crashes in Turkey
DOC.TEXT: Two separate bus crashes in central and eastern Turkey on Sunday killed 19 people and injured 65, state-run radio said. The radio said a bus traveling from the eastern city of Van to Ankara collided head-on with another bus near Darende township in the eastern province of Malatya, killing 12 people and injuring 40. Seven people were killed and 25 injured when a bus skidded off the road and plunged into a ravine near Akdagmadeni township in the central province of Yozgat, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Nine People Drown When Makeshift Ferry Capsizes
DOC.TEXT: A makeshift ferry capsized in northwestern Egypt, killing nine people, a police source said Sunday. The ferry owner was arrested and accused of operating the craft without a license. The ferry, made of eight barrels and several planks of wood, capsized Saturday afternoon with 14 people aboard, the source said. The fatalities included seven children between the ages of 12 and 16 and two 27-year-old men. The craft had operated daily, taking residents of Nag el-Tabadsha across a canal to the other side of their small village. Many of its regular passengers were schoolchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Man Killed at Celebrations Watched by Princess Anne, Bush's Son
DOC.TEXT: Police shot and killed an elderly man at independence celebrations Sunday attended by Britain's Princess Anne, Nigerian leader Ibrahim Babangida and one of President Bush's sons, witnesses said. Senior security sources confirmed an unidentified man was killed but said he died when a gun accidentally discharged. Witnesses said a policeman aimed and shot at the man as he tried to get into the stadium where the celebrations of this West African nation's 25th anniversary of independence from Britain were held. President Sir Dawda Jawara and his guests _ who included the daughter of Britain's Queen Elizabeth, George Bush Jr. and the Nigerian leader _ apparently were unaware of the shooting.

DOC.HEAD: Military Court Sentences Hashish Dealer to Death
DOC.TEXT: Sudan's military court system, which has been criticized for its harsh sentences, convicted a man of dealing hashish and condemned him to death by hanging, state-run television reported. Hamid Mohamed Hamad became the second man sentenced to death for hashish trafficking since the military government came to power June 30. Saturday night's TV report did not say how much of the drug he sold. The military courts also have handed out death sentences to four people convicted of trading currency on the black market and to a man found guilty of leading a strike by doctors in Sudan in August. When it came to power, Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir's government decreed harsh criminal laws. The death sentences handed out under those laws have been sharply criticized by Arab and Western nations.

DOC.HEAD: Report Experts Call for Law Limiting Families to Four Children
DOC.TEXT: Population experts alarmed by the lack of response to birth control programs are urging the government to pass a law limiting families to four children, an independent newspaper reported Sunday. The Nigerian Guardian said official projections based on an estimated national average of every woman bearing seven children indicate it will take at least 20 years before any population policy makes an impact on the nation's 3.4 percent growth rate. Nigeria's population of 115 million is the largest in Africa and one of the fastest growing in the world. Officials project that it could reach 165 million within a decade. ``The nation's population is difficult to control because the momentum for the present growth rate is already established,'' the newspaper quoted Dr. A.B. Sulaiman as saying. Sulaiman, the architect of Nigeria's birth control program and executive director of its Planned Parenthood Federation, said he believed there was a national desire to reduce population growth, but doubted it could succeed while at least 50 percent of the population is young and sexually active. Worried population experts have sent a report to the government urging enactment of a law to force people to limit their families to four children, the newspaper reported without identifying the experts. It said they urged the government to abandon its sensitivity to cultural issues that frown on birth control and to concentrate on freeing the next generation from poverty, hunger, disease, social disorder, mass suicides and other byproducts of over-population. Traditions and polygamy tolerated culturally and by the Moslem religion of many Nigerians encourage large families. They are considered a sign of a man's wealth and virility and also provide free labor for family holdings in the agriculture-based countryside. Birth control now can ``prevent the situation from getting worse for the next generation and ensure that youth embrace family planning as a social ethic so that past mistakes are not perpetuated,'' Sulaiman said. But he concluded that only wars, earthquakes, floods, famine, epidemics and other disasters could reduce the population or stall its frightening growth rate before the year 2010.

DOC.HEAD: Early Works of Composer Edward Elgar Discovered
DOC.TEXT: Several unknown pieces by composer Edward Elgar, whose ``Pomp and Circumstance'' is a fixture at U.S. graduation ceremonies, have been discovered, but they are minor works, a local writer said. ``There is no great symphony I'm afraid, no great works of art,'' William Mitchell said Saturday. He said he acquired the manuscripts last year. The early pieces were discovered in Giggleswick, a Yorkshire town the composer frequently visited. They include a trio for violin, piano and cello, an arrangement of the Yorkshire ballad ``Clapham Town End,'' and a setting of a poem. ``Clapham Town End'' is a song about two dealers ``trying to flog a dead horse on the other _ or one a dead horse and the other a dying one,'' Mitchell said. Elgar, who died in 1934, is known for his later compositions such as ``The Dream of Gerontius'' and ``Land of Hope and Glory.''

DOC.HEAD: Future Princess Casts Her Last Vote
With AM-Japan-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Sunday's election probably was the last for college student Kiko Kawashima. The 23-year-old will lose her eligibility to vote when she marries Emperor Akihito's younger son this spring. The future princess cast her ballot at a polling center near the prestigious Gakushuin University, where she is studying post-graduate level pyschology and where her father teaches economics. After choosing one of the eight parliamentary candidates in her home district's hotly contested race, Miss Kawashima turned to a crowd of reporters and photographers, bowed and quickly left. By law, members of Japan's royal family are not allowed to vote in elections or run for public office. Miss Kawashima, who has won many admirers with her gentle, polite demeanor and warm smile, is to marry Prince Aya, 24, in late June. Aya is second in line to the throne.

DOC.HEAD: Plan To Split Largest Appeals Court Divides Industry, Environmentalists
DOC.TEXT: Environmental and industry groups are on opposite sides of a dispute over whether to break up the nation's largest appeals court, which exercises authority across nine states and far into the Pacific. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, with jurisdiction over more than 40 million Americans from its base in San Francisco, is frequently the arbiter of major environmental cases. ``This huge circuit requires too much travel and has too many judges handing down too many opinions that breed inconsistency and lack of uniformity,'' says Sen. Slade Gorton, R-Wash. Joined by eight other senators, Gorton is proposing to cut the 9th Circuit into two parts and establish a new appeals circuit based in Seattle. The timber industry supports Gorton's plan, while environmentalists wince at the notion of taking jurisdiction over major lawsuits out of California and moving it to timber country. Similarly, Pacific Northwest senators find themselves at odds with Californians. ``The real criticism of the bill supporters is aimed at the outcome of some of the environmental litigation and what the bill sponsors would do is a backdoor way of influencing these decisions,'' says Nan Aron, head of the Alliance for Justice, a court-watching group based in the nation's capital. Courtroom dueling between timber companies and environmentalists has focused on the northern spotted owl. The 2-pound bird nests exclusively in the Douglas fir trees of ``old growth'' forests in the Pacific Northwest. Environmentalists say more cutting could threaten the spotted owl _ to say nothing of the forests themselves _ with extinction. Portland, Ore., attorney Mark Rutzick, an outspoken advocate of the timber industry, says creating a Seattle-based appeals court ``would result in decisions based on a sounder understanding of the circumstances.'' ``There's a world of difference between the California life experience and life in a small, timber-dependent community in Oregon or Washington,'' he says. ``Availability of trees for a sawmill to process is life or death for a small town.'' Such views have caused environmental groups including the Sierra Club and the National Wildlife Federation to head in an opposite direction. Vic Sher, a Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund attorney based in Seattle, takes issue with ``the notion that federal courts of appeals should be bastions of provincialism.'' ``One of the reasons for having the court of appeals is to insure the removal of the court from the immediate concerns of the community,'' he says. But he doubted that merely moving appeals of environmental cases northward would automatically change the outcome. ``We bring good cases,'' he said. ``We assume the court will continue to decide on the law.'' Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., however, said in a Dec. 5 letter to National Wildlife Federation chief Jay D. Hair that he believes the outcome of cases could change under the proposed new system. ``This legislation is not in the best interests of judicial administration and it could also undercut the effectiveness of important decisions protecting the environment in the western United States,'' Wilson said. Aides to Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., say he plans to be on hand March 6 to oppose the bill at a hearing before a Senate Judiciary Committee panel headed by Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala. Gorton's bill would leave Arizona, California and Nevada in smaller 9th Circuit. It would create a new 12th Circuit, with jurisdiction over Alaska, Idaho, Hawaii, Montana, Oregon and Washington, as well as Guam and the Northern Marianas thousands of miles away in the Pacific. With California senators opposed, efforts to restructure the court are likely to face tough sledding this year. Bill proponents argue that the size of the 9th Circuit requires too much travel on the part of lawyers. Critics counter that court papers may be filed locally in all the states in the circuit, and they say there would be little difference between traveling to San Francisco or Seattle for lawyers from Montana or Alaska. Proponents also say that because of the court's size it is inefficient. Critics say it already has divided itself into two administrative units and now is a model of efficiency. Bill opponents note that the circuit's active judges are unanimous in opposing the bill. Supporters point to other judges who favor it. Timber lobbyists, meanwhile, say they have not been active in pushing for the legislation. They do make clear, however, that the industry is smiling on the idea. ``It seems to us,'' says William Murray, American Forest Resource Alliance counsel, ``that certainly Senator Gorton and the other senators have identified legitimate concerns with regard to judicial administration in the 9th Circuit, which I think has been regarded for some time as being overlarge and overworked.''

DOC.HEAD: Indian Government Grounds Airbus-320s
DOC.TEXT: The government Sunday grounded all 13 Airbus-320s operating with state-owned Indian Airlines pending an investigation into a crash last week that killed 91 people, news reports said. The 150-seat plane, the only passenger aircraft with fully computerized flight control capabilities, will be grounded until all aspects of its operation are investigated, the United News of India said, citing unidentified officials. The news agency said pilots had criticized the use of the plane by Indian Airlines because its sophisticated technology required commensurate ground maintenance, which was not available in India. On Wednesday, a 3-month-old Airbus-320 crashed while it was coming in to land at Bangalore airport, killing 91 of the 146 people on board. Indian Airlines, which flies to 73 cities in India and nine nearby countries, placed an order for 31 Airbus-320s last year. It has received 14 of the planes, each costing $38 million. The cause of Wednesday's crash remained a mystery. The weather was clear and the pilot had not reported any emergency. The aircraft, on a scheduled flight from Bombay, grazed a clump of trees short of the runway, crashed and caught fire. Newspapers have said the pilot tried to manually take over the plane's computer control minutes before the landing. An Indian Airlines spokesman said newspaper reports were incorrect and that nothing could be said until inquiries were completed. Both the pilot and the co-pilot died in the crash, and the inquiry is centering on the cockpit voice recorder and fight data recorder. The crash was only the second involving the Airbus-320, which is manufactured by Airbus Industrie, a European consortium based in Toulouse, France. In the previous crash, at an air show in eastern France in June 1988, three people were killed and 50 were injured. In that accident, the company blamed pilot error before investigations were completed. The pilot, Michel Asseline, told investigators that the engines responded late to efforts to gain altitude. But Airbus Industrie denied there were any problems with the plane and the French government suspended Asseline's pilot's license for eight years. The twin-engined, narrow-bodied jet consumes 40 percent less fuel than similar planes and has been making inroads into the medium-range market, long dominated by Boeing and McDonnell Douglas. Airbus Industrie says it is the fastest selling plane in aircraft history.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter Taken From His Home by Armed Men
DOC.TEXT: The Colombo correspondent for a Rome-based news agency was taken from his home by six armed men, and family members said Sunday they were told he was being held by the army for questioning. Police sources said the reporter, 33-year-old Richard de Zoysa, was removed from his home in the Welikade suburb of the capital Saturday morning by six men carrying guns. Five were dressed as civilians, and one as a policeman, they said. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, denied the reporter had been arrested and said they suspected the journalist was abducted by Sinhalese militants fighting to overthrow the government. De Zoysa, a Sinhalese, works for the Inter Press Service, which is based in Rome and has correspondents in many capitals around the world. He had also written several articles on the Sinhalese uprising for local newspapers. On Sunday, members of de Zoysa's family said Maj. Gen. Cecil Waidyaratne, the army commander for the Colombo area, told them the reporter was being held for questioning at an army detention camp. They said he refused to elaborate. Sinhalese extremists of the People's Liberation Front have been accused of killing three employees of the state-owned television network last year. At least 6,000 people have been killed by guerrillas and authorities since the Sinhalese uprising began in 1987. The militants claim the government has made too many concessions to Tamil militants fighting for more autonomy in northern and eastern Sri Lanka.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Nationalists Complain Gorbachev Reforms Bringing Misery
LaserPhoto MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: Right-wing Russian nationalists staged a venomous rally Sunday to complain about President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms, warming U.S.-Soviet relations and the growing nationalism in non-Russian republics. The 2,000 people gathered in the deep snow near Soviet TV's 1,600-foot-tall transmission tower also heard speakers accuse Gorbachev of being power-hungry and plunging the Soviet Union into poverty and misery. Ironically, the right-wing groups were taking advantage of Gorbachev's glasnost policy of greater openness to counter liberal measures they believe are hurting the Russians, the country's dominant ethnic population. The harshest attack on Gorbachev came from Boris Unko of the United Front of Workers of Russia, a group fighting Gorbachev's market-oriented economic reforms and unhappy about the nationalism in non-Russian republics. Unko told the crowd that the people initially supported perestroika, Gorbachev's reform program, but that ``today we see what we got from that.'' Among the evils wrought by Gorbachev's reforms, Unko said, were rock music, ``modernism and pornography,'' ``insults'' to heroes of the Bolshevik Revolution and World War II and others ``who built socialist society.'' He said Gorbachev had sold out to the elite and forgotten about the working class. ``Today we very much want to understand: Is that a result of some kind of mistake or unfortunate circumstances?'' Unko demanded. He said Gorbachev is trying to become a dictator, adding that the Soviet leader should have known his reforms would bring more harm than good. ``Any grandmother could have predicted the consequences of such a course. But you keep different company, the elite, property-holders. You make friends with President-murderer Bush, also a fighter for democracy who spilled blood in much-suffering Panama,'' Unko said. Although ethnic Russians, including Gorbachev, dominate the Soviet leadership, Russian nationalists feel forsaken by the Kremlin and its economic and political liberalization and adhere to orthodox socialism. Russians also feel threatened by other nationalities who have been speaking out against what they see as imperialistic policies that have encroached on local languages and cultures and plundered natural resources. Sunday's rally reflected the increasing polarization that has occurred as the Soviet Union's more than 100 ethnic groups vent long pent-up grievances. Russian nationalists have become particularly vocal during the campaign for March 4 elections to the republic's legislature. Small knots of people huddled at the demonstration to talk politics and buy leaflets and newspapers published by Russian nationalist groups. One written statement described a purported plot to seize power being hatched by liberal parliamentarians in the Inter-Regional Group, whose leaders included Russian populist Boris N. Yeltsin. The statement, signed by a patriotic group called ``Russia,'' said the coup would occur in the second half of March and that the instigators were hording hundreds of train wagons of consumer goods for distribution after they take power. Banners resting against a fence attacked Gorbachev. They read, ``Mikhail is the Creator of Vileness and Desolation'' and ``Gorbachev: Answer for the Breakdown of the Economy.'' One banner held by protesters blasted Gorbachev's proposal, made at a meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee two weeks ago, to strengthen the presidency, a post he now holds. ``No Fascism under the Guise of a Presidency,'' the poster read. A candidate in the March 4 elections, Alexander I. Dorpayev, accused economic reformers of purposely leading the economy to collapse so they could impose capitalism to benefit ``underground millionaires.'' Speakers obliquely criticized Soviet Jews who emigrate, and one woman held a poster attacking Jews. ``Russians: Purge the National Staff of Doctors, Medicine, of Zionist-Murderer-Butcherers,'' her poster read.

DOC.HEAD: Privacy Not a Big Issue at Japanese Voting Centers
With AM-Japan-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Unlike U.S. elections with their mechanized and curtained booths, in Japan it's all done by hand at rows of tables with only a hint of privacy. As a result, many a ballot was cast in Sunday's parliamentary elections after furtive glances at neighbors or the outright comparing of notes. A young couple standing side-by-side at desks separated only by low partitions in one suburban polling center discussed the merits of each candidate in their district before agreeing on a mutually acceptable member of the opposition Socialist Party. An elderly woman nearby filled in a ballot for her husband, who was cradling their grandson. Voters outside gathered for one final look at photographs of the candidates on campaign posters, which had to conform to government size regulations to be pasted on the center's official billboard. One housewife said she went to the center undecided but chose a Liberal Democrat after examining his poster. ``He looked the most respectable of the bunch,'' she said. The election for the 512 seats in the powerful lower house of Japan's bicameral Parliament was seen as a crucial test of whether scandals and unpopular policies would end the Liberal Democrats' more than three decades of control over the government. More than 90 million people age 20 or older were eligible to vote, and officials said about 73 percent cast ballots. Those unable to pencil in their vote on the light green ballots because of physical disability, illiteracy or other reason were able to designate proxies to vote for them. The counting of the votes began immediately after most centers closed at 6 p.m., and the first ``assured winner'' based on computer projections was declared just 90 minutes later on publicly supported television. But difficulties were expected in counting the handwritten votes, which could be nullified for misspellings or unnecessary markings. And because voters have been known to write only the family name of their chosen candidate, problems also were expected in one district where three Satos were in the running and in another that had three Kogas. In a separate ballot Sunday, a national referendum was held on the performance of eight of Japan's 15 Supreme Court judges. The eight took their seats after the last such poll, during elections for both houses of Parliament in 1986. Spaces were provided for voters to mark if they thought any of the Cabinet-appointed justices should be removed. The system was written into the constitution by U.S.-led occupation forces after World War II to provide a safeguard against unpopular appointees, but it has been criticized as ineffective. No justice has resigned because of a poor rating, and critics say many voters do not know the backgrounds of the judges they are rating well enough to render a fair decision. That charge was reflected by the young wife at the suburban polling center, who held out her ballot to her husband and asked: ``Do you know any of these people?''

DOC.HEAD: Internal Revenue: From Bumbling Bureaucrats to Political Vendettas
DOC.TEXT: Horror stories abound about the federal agency everyone loves to hate: the Internal Revenue Service. One of the earliest dates to 1925, when the nation's chief tax-collection agency _ then the Bureau of Internal Revenue _ and its parent Treasury Department responded to a senator's allegations of widespread corruption by slapping him with a $10.8 million bill for back taxes. There is considerable evidence that the IRS sometimes has been used against political enemies, especially during the Franklin D. Roosevelt, Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon administrations. Just last year a congressional subcommittee held hearings on allegations of outright fraud and bribery involving senior IRS officials. Then there are the almost-comical examples of a bumbling bureaucracy _ the wrongful seizure of children's bank accounts and the expenditure of huge amounts of time and money to recover a few dollars in back taxes. These and other stories are recounted by David Burnham in ``A Law Unto Itself: Power, Politics and the IRS.'' With its sprawling bureaucracy of 125,000 employees, an unpopular task and a seeming susceptibility to shooting itself in the foot, the IRS is an easy target. But Burnham rejects the excuse that there are bound to be occasional foulups in any organization so big. ``The rapid turnover at the very top of the IRS, the recruitment of most of its top administrators from within and the almost complete lack of outside review make the agency astonishingly consistent in the often erratic and hard-nosed way it deals with the American people,'' Burnham writes. Only two IRS officials _ the commissioner and the chief counsel _ are appointed by the president and confirmed by the Senate, Burnham notes, and since World War II the average tenure of the commissioner has been 37 months. Stepping into that leadership vacuum, he contends, is ``a small unknown cadre of senior civil servants who have spent their entire careers slowly inching up the agency's promotion ladder.'' For the most part, Burnham says, these career officials are conservatives with a ``suspicious, almost paranoid, mind-set.'' All too often, he adds, the agency's power is brought to bear against those whose chief crime is that they ``offend the sensibilities of an agency bureaucrat.'' Burnham blames Congress for many IRS problems. He says the House and Senate shirk their responsibility to oversee the IRS for fear that a crackdown could deter collection of the taxes that finance the programs that lawmakers love. The IRS is hampered by an organizational structure and an outmoded computer system that were dictated by Congress to disperse the agency's authority in the wake of a major 1950s scandal and Watergate abuses. A former New York Times reporter, Burnham blames the news media for failing to cover the IRS as thoroughly as it does, say, the Justice Department. And he criticizes academics for showing far more interest in the tax laws than how they are administered. Burnham acknowledges that the IRS does its basic job well, collecting 90 cents of every tax dollar owed, about $1 trillion a year. Except for writing that he talked to dozens of IRS employees whose integrity seemed beyond question, he has little else that is good to say about the agency. Even the praise for workers' integrity is tempered by a note that many ``expressed such despair about the ability of the agency to function in a fair way that their will to perform a decent day's work appeared to have been seriously undermined.'' The IRS has declined to comment on the book. But even as the book was making its appearance, the IRS was acknowledging publicly that ``we have made mistakes and we have identified systemic weaknesses and areas that can and should be improved.'' IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. made those statements in a report on how the agency is responding to allegations, including some made by Burnham and others by investigators for a House subcommittee, about ethical lapses among some senior officials. If most Americans are unaware of some of the problems of the IRS, they probably are familiar with what Burnham views as a root cause. ``In a situation where both the enforcers and the subjects of enforcement are unable to fathom the intent of the law,'' Burnham writes, ``arbitrary and capricious actions are inevitable. ... ``It is hard to imagine how reforms can be made within the administrative process until Congress and the public understand that the agency's genuine flaws begin with truly impossible tax laws,'' he concludes.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: This year's winner of the 10th annual Strange Music Festival was a hosaphone. Runner-up honors went to a harp that came from from the broad side of a barn. Third place went to the humongaphonium. The festival began in 1980 at Carter Caves State Resort Park and was intended originally to celebrate the jaw harp. ``But we decided that was too limited, so the thing just started getting a whole lot bigger,'' said festival co-founder Dick Albin, a Nashville, Tenn., humorist. Albin said the festival has attracted musicians from Japan, Israel, Canada and West Virginia. Previous winners include a baby's bottom and a dog's tail. ``This brings out latent musical abilities,'' said John P. Tierney, park naturalist and the other co-founder. More than 100 people squeezed into the meeting room at the park lodge to watch six musicians demonstrate their creations. Prizes went to the instruments that were the most unusual and the best able to play a recognizable tune. Dick Mansfield, a folk musician from Mansfield, Ohio, won what he called a hosaphone. He took the mouthpiece from a trumpet and stuck it into a hose from his mother's washing machine. Twirling one end of the hose, he played taps. ``I came up with this 30 years ago but never had a place to play it,'' Mansfield said. Robert Toothman of South Point, Ohio, came in second with his board harp, a 5-foot-4 piece of lumber from the side of an old barn that he fitted with frets and banjo strings. Third-place went to J.C. Ramey of Olive Hill, a former elementary school principal who said he spent a year developing his entry, which he called a gigantic, compressed-air, PVC humongaphonium. It was a long piece of plastic pipe with a slide in one end and an air compressor on the other. With the help of two assistants, he played ``The Ol' Gray Mare.'' Tierney said this year's entries werent as strange as some he'd seen. ``We had a very bizarre instrument a while back,'' he said. ``This couple had a baby, and they figured out that if they patted him, he'd gurgle, so they played that.'' Another contestant tied a stick to a dog's wagging tail so the animal could play the drums. ``Visually it was strange,'' Tierney said, ``but musically, it was lacking something.''

Poor George Washington. In six New Jersey communities that took his name as their own, not a single parade or commemoration celebrated the 258th anniversary of his birth. ``I guess I'm glad we're not planning anything,'' said Betty Bartkovsky, secretary to the mayor of Washington Township in Morris County. ``If we were doing anything, I'd probably have to come to work Monday.'' New Jersey has five separate communities named Washington Township and one called Washington Borough. Each City Hall has its own tale of confusion and bureaucratic chaos caused by the proliferation of Washingtons. ``I sometimes wonder why anyone would name their town after Washington with five others already there,'' said Marjorie Fox, township clerk in Gloucester County's version, the largest of the six with 35,000 residents. ``We get all the wrong death certificates, birth certificates, tax payments. It's a real problem.'' One of the communities took steps to ease the confusion. Washington Borough, a one-square-mile Warren County enclave, seceded from Washington Township to distinguish itself from other Washingtons. Washington knew his way around New Jersey. He led the Continental Army through New Jersey several times during the Revolutionary War, fighting the British at Trenton, Monmouth and Princeton. He also briefly made his headquarters in Essex County and then in Morristown. One place did remember its roots over the holiday weekend: Washington's Crossing State Park in Mercer County, which marks the spot where the general landed in New Jersey after his Christmas Eve crossing of the Delaware River in 1776. ``We're having an open house 18th-century celebration with musicians, hostesses and plenty of food and crafts,'' said Nancy Carter, supervisor of the ferry house at the park. Melissa Opdyke, the municipal clerk in neighboring Washington Township _ in Warren County, that is _ said the U.S. Postal Service had solved the confusion. ``We're the only Washington Township with our own postal code,'' she said proudly. ``Bergen County's Washington Township is part of Westwood, Morris County's is in Long Valley, Mercer's is in Robbinsville, Gloucester's is in Turnersville and Burlington's is in Egg Harbor.'' That should clear up the problem, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Four Reported Killed as Demonstrators Demand Multiparty System
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New thruout to UPDATE with four people reported killed. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators demanding restoration of a multiparty democracy clashed with police in at least five cities Sunday, and three protesters and one policeman were killed, witnesses and official reports said. More than 475 people were reported arrested and about 15 people were injured on the first day of a mass campaign to demand an end to the 29-year-old ban on political parties. In the capital, Katmandu, police used tear gas and clubs to disperse thousands of chanting protesters, some of whom threw stones and bricks at an official rally. State-run Radio Nepal reported from Hetauda, 72 miles south of Katmandu, that one policeman died of head injuries and two other policemen and at least half a dozen demonstrators were hurt in scuffles. Two demonstrators were killed when police opened fire in Bharatpur, 75 miles southeast of the capital, official sources said. Witnesses contacted from Katmandu said police also opened fire in the midwestern city of Tansen, killing one demonstrator. They said 30 demonstrators were arrested in Tansen and another 45 people in nearby Pokhara. The demonstrators in Katmandu, mostly young people, unfurled flags of the outlawed Nepali Congress Party and shouted ``We want democracy!'' and ``Down with the panchayat system!'' _ set up in 1960 when King Birendra accused the government of misusing power and banned all political parties. Police detained about 200 demonstrators in the city of 235,000. Students said more than 200 of their colleagues at Tribhuvan University were rounded up early Sunday to keep them from joining the march. The students had tried to evade police by spending the night in a nearby town. Activists hurled stones and bricks as a government-sponsored procession of more than 80,000 people, led by Prime Minister Marich Man Singh Shrestha, moved through the streets, chanting ``We love our king and queen more than our lives'' and other slogans opposing the protesters. State radio said seven people in the procession were hurt. The official march was to mark Nepal's 40th National Democracy Day, the anniversary of the end of 104 years of rule by the autocratic Rana family. In his message for the occasion, carried by official media, the king said democracy demands respect for the majority's verdict. In a national referendum in 1980, Nepal voted against restoring a multiparty system. The number of anti-government demonstrators swelled from about 100 at the beginning to several thousand. About 200 riot police stood guard. Joining the socialist-leaning Congress Party in the demonstration was the United Left Front, an umbrella organization of Communist Party factions. Front activists unfurled red flags emblazoned with the hammer and sickle. ``I have never seen such flags in all my life,'' said fruit vendor Asha Khadgi. The demonstrators marched about a half-mile down Katmandu's main thoroughfare before police dispersed them with tear gas. Later, they formed small groups that spread in different directions and were charged by club-wielding riot police. The government accused the parties who led Sunday's action of trying to impose their version of democracy on this Himilayan nation, which they say already has a working democracy. After the 1980 referendum, Nepalese were given the right to elect their representatives directly from their constituencies. Now, 112 members are elected from 75 districts, and the remaining 28 are nominees of the king. Only an elected member is eligible to become prime minister.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Movie director Spike Lee urged his alma mater to ban fraternities as he accepted an achievement award from the school, Morehouse College. He also said he was kicked off campus while filming there in 1987. ``During this past semester, a young man ... died,'' Lee said, referring to Joel Harris, an 18-year-old who officials said died of a heart ailment after hazing from potential fraternity brothers. ``I think we should abolish fraternities from Morehouse's campus.'' Lee appeared at the Atlanta campus Saturday to be honored for his achievements. He received a 1990 Bennie Award, handed out each year as part of the all-male college's Founders Days celebrations. Lee also scolded Morehouse administrators, claiming they kicked him off campus in 1987 while he was filming ``School Daze,'' which portrayed a caste system based on skin color among blacks at a mythical black college. ``After three weeks of shooting here, we were kicked off campus,'' said Lee, a 1979 Morehouse graduate. ``We were told that this whole color thing was irrelevant. Now in Atlanta there's a court case where a light-skinned woman is suing a dark-skinned woman.'' Lee referred to Tracy Lynn Morrow, who sued her former employer, the Internal Revenue Service, claiming her supervisor, a dark-skinned black, fired her unfairly. The case is pending. ``The reason I made the film was to show the petty differences that keep black people from being a unified people,'' said Lee, who received a standing ovation. ``At no time did I think this film would be a negative portrayal of blacks in higher education or Morehouse as a whole.'' Morehouse President Leroy Keith Jr. denied Lee's claims. ``I was not here at the time that happened. Morehouse has always been proud of Spike Lee,'' Keith said. ``I think there was just a disagreement over the process for approval for filming on campus.'' Lee, 32, was nominated for an Academy Award last week for the screenplay he wrote for his latest film, ``Do the Right Thing.''

Actress Kathleen Turner bowed out of a weekend matinee performance of ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' here because of a bout with laryngitis that had dragged on for two days. Turner missed the performance of the Tennessee Williams play on Saturday at the Shubert Theater in Boston on the orders of her doctor. The theater reported that officials expect Turner to be well enough for the rest of her scheduled performances. The play, which also stars Charles Durning, is slated to run here until Feb. 25, before a Broadway opening. ``Her doctor would not allow her to perform for six hours in one day,'' said usher Gene Marley III. ``I guess with her musky voice and the length of the performance, it's taken a toll.'' Turner is known for her film performances, including ``Body Heat'' and ``Jewel of the Nile'' and the current ``War of the Roses.''

A promoter wants to bring the pop band New Kids on the Block back to Memphis after two sellout concerts last week matched an attendance record set by superstar Bruce Springsteen. Bob Kelley, head of Mid-South Concerts, said the New Kids tied a Mid-South Coliseum record, drawing 22,471 fans to two shows, Wednesday and Thursday. Kelley said two Springsteen shows in 1984 drew that same number. Every seat in the coliseum was sold for the shows as fans bought tickets for behind the stage. The New Kids won't be back in Memphis soon. Kelley says the group is booked solid for months. Hits for the young group, known for a positive attitude and anti-drug message, include ``This One's For the Childen'' and ``I'll Be Loving You Forever.''

Grammy Award nominee Gordon Hartmann says he got his start by sneaking into his grandmother's basement at age 4 to play with an old wooden accordian. At the time, he didn't want anyone to hear as he mimicked his father and uncles, who played polka music in local bands. ``Of course, at that age, you don't realize that everyone upstairs can hear you anyway,'' Hartmann said. Hartmann, 28, a Madison songwriter and bandleader, has introduced the old ``oompah band'' style polka to digital recording technology. Hartmann is a finalists for a Grammy Award in the polka music category for his second album ``Polkaholic.'' The ceremonies are scheduled Wednesday in Los Angeles.

Craig Claiborne, food writer for The New York Times, faces a charge of driving while intoxicated stemming from a two-car accident last weekend, police said Sunday. Claiborne was arrested after his car collided with another at an intersection in East Hampton on Feb. 9, said East Hampton police Lt. John Claflin. No one was injured. Claiborne, 69, was released on his own recognizance by East Hampton Judge Edward Horne.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Rebels Attack Power Station
DOC.TEXT: Leftist rebels attacked an electric substation, knocking out power briefly and injuring a guard, before they were repelled by army soldiers, the military said Sunday. The skirmish Saturday night in the western part of the capital did not result in long or widespread power outages, the military statement said. No injuries to soldiers of the U.S.-supported government or to rebels of that Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front were reported. The last major rebel offensive occurred in November when more than 1,000 people were killed in fighting in and around San Salvador. In his Sunday homily, San Salvador's Roman Catholic archbishop, Arturo Rivera Damas, said that government policies and rebel attacks were causing great hardship to the nation's people. ``The pain has been immense,'' he said. ``The voice of our Lord is resonating strongly on all horizons to say that violence brings about more violence, that only love can build a new world.''

DOC.HEAD: Hostage's Sister Salutes Arafat, Recounts Frustration
DOC.TEXT: Peggy Say paid tribute Sunday to PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat for his efforts in trying to free the 18 Western hostages in Lebanon, including her brother, the longest-held of the captives. In an hour-long meeting Saturday, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization told Mrs. Say that he was doing his ``very best'' to win the release of the hostages but did not go into details. ``I was pleased to meet him after waiting such a long time to come face to face with him,'' Mrs. Say told The Associated Press. ``I was encouraged that he said he would do his very best, which is all I could ask of anybody.'' Mrs. Say is the sister of Terry Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985 and believed held by Shiite Moslem extremists with close ties to Iran. ``I am sure (Arafat) will do whatever he can if he should find himself in a position to do something,'' Mrs. Say said. ``Unfortunately, he has no direct influence on the kidnappers, but he is a player in the Middle East and it's my job to approach anyone who might help.'' Mrs. Say is on a ``humanitarian pilgrimage'' to gather international support for the release of Anderson and the other hostages. Thus far, she has met U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, Pope John Paul II and leading officials of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France. Mrs. Say is accompanied on her tour by Don Mell, the AP photographer who was with Anderson when he was abducted, and Larry Heinzerling, a deputy director of the AP which supports Mrs. Say's efforts financially and logistically in pressing its own efforts to win Anderson's release. A group calling itself Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, is believed to be holding Anderson and Terry Waite, special envoy of Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie, who disappeared Jan. 20, 1987 while trying to negotiate the release of the hostages. Arafat received Mrs. Say during a luncheon with a group of friends and supporters in his luxurious, well-guarded mansion overlooking the Mediterranean in suburban Gammarth. The Palestinian leader invited Mrs. Say to sit next to him at the long table and showed her the Arab fashion of eating roast lamb with his fingers. ``I liked him personally,'' Mrs. Say declared. ``He was very charming and sympathetic, particularly in listening to my problems, which may seem small when compared with the many problems he must have to contend with himself.'' Mrs. Say leaves Monday for Paris, where she will meet UNESCO Director General Federico Mayor, later heading to Damascus for a meeting with Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk Al-Sharaa and then Canterbury, England to meet Runcie. ``What is discouraging is that I've been making this trek for five years now,'' Mrs. Say said, ``and I never met anyone who said he could solve it. It is always a complicated circuit through a series of other people.'' Arafat told her the man with the greatest possible influence would be President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran, but that his room for maneuvering is limited by hard-liners in his government. Mrs. Say said she still hoped to get permission to visit Iran, although her many visa applications have gone unanswered. In all, eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman are believed held captive.
