DOC.TEXT: Moments after the curtain fell on his performance in a Verdi opera at the Kennedy Center, Soviet tenor Vladimir Popov played the leading role in an emotional backstage drama when he received his U.S. citizenship papers from Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia. ``This is the greatest day in my life,'' declared Popov, who fell to his knees, crossed himself and grinned broadly. ``I'm a little bit nervous.'' Popov, 42, the son of a retired Soviet army general, defected in 1982 in Milan, Italy, while on leave from the Bolshoi Opera to study Italian repertoire at La Scala. He sought asylum at the U.S. consulate in Milan wearing only a T-shirt and a pair of jeans. On Saturday night, Popov sang with prima donna Aprile Millo in the Washington Opera's first production of the Giuseppe Verdi spectacular, ``Aida,'' before a sold-out audience in the Kennedy Center Opera House. After taking his bows at the footlights, Popov joined his American-born wife, Lucy, backstage for a joyful celebration with a small circle of friends and well-wishers. Still wearing the heavy makeup and glittering robes of the opera's Egyptian war hero, Radames, the stocky tenor was greeted by a black-robed Scalia, the son of a Sicilian immigrant and a self-confessed opera lover. ``I am delighted to welcome you to the land of the free and the home of the brave,'' said Scalia, who gave the singer his citizenship papers encased in a red-framed album with ``Vladimir Popov'' printed in gold letters on the black leather cover. ``The reason you gave for coming to America was that you wanted a choice,'' said Scalia, ``the choice to be the person you want to be and to perfect all your abilities.'' Popov beamed, sighed and responded to the applause in Russian style by applauding back. Later, at a black-tie cast party, Popov wore an American flag pin on his tuxedo lapel as Washington Opera general director Martin Feinstein hailed ``our newest American citizen and a wonderful human being.'' Popov interrupted rehearsals for ``Aida'' on Friday to fly to snowbound New Hampshire to take his oath as a naturalized citizen from a federal judge in Concord. After reciting the Pledge of Allegiance, Popov turned to his wife and said: ``Now I've got my second voice. I can vote now.'' Mrs. Popov, the daughter of Ukrainian immigrants, said her husband plans to cast his first vote on March 13 in municipal elections in their hometown of Wentworth, N.H. Her brother, Vitaly, is a candidate for selectman on the local town council. In an interview earlier in the week, Popov said he defected because of the suffocating bureaucracy and limited repertoire of the Bolshoi Opera, where talented young singers were suppressed in favor of a ``clique'' of aging stars chosen by seniority. ``My progress was so slow,'' he said in halting English. ``I sing a little bit here and a little bit there, but they always say `this is not your time' or `no, you only learn one opera in two years.''' ``It was a matter of having choices,'' he says. ``In the Soviet Union you have no choices. You are told what to sing, when and where to sing it. Here we have choices. That's really the number one reason.'' His life has changed quickly since he defected in Milan on April 29, 1982 _ his 35th birthday. He arrived in New York two days later. He soon met Lucy, his volunteer interpreter, and married her a few months later. He auditioned for the Washington Opera on their honeymoon, and made his debut with the Metropolitan Opera in New York in 1984. This year, Popov has been signed to sing in 30 operas, concerts and recitals across the country and abroad, including La Scala this summer, the opening of the Vienna State Opera's 1990-91 season next fall and a return engagement at the Met next winter. When he's not touring, Popov enjoys cross-country skiing and boating on his 32-acre farm in the New Hampshire mountains, or sipping a beer while watching Charles Bronson and Arnold Schwarzenegger action videos at home. ``He's a couch potato,'' his wife says. Popov said he was cursed as a traitor by Communist Party bosses, and his defection was bitterly opposed by his military father. ``For the first year or more, I had bad dreams every night that they would come and take me away,'' Popov said. But he says he's never had any regrets. ``Right now I have a different life,'' he says, laughing. ``What could I do in Russia now? Drink vodka maybe.''

DOC.BYLINE: Prosecutors Prepare to Fill In Final Pieces of Exxon Valdez Puzzle. ^By LINDA DEUTSCH
DOC.TEXT: After two weeks of testimony, prosecutors plan to wind up the case against Joseph Hazelwood by offering a few more pieces of the Exxon Valdez puzzle and some expert witnesses to put it all together. Navigation experts are expected to testify as well as those who have studied the effects of alcohol over long periods. Coast Guardsmen who went aboard the crippled vessel in the hours after it hit a jagged reef are likely to provide accounts of the final hours in Hazelwood's ordeal at sea. The 987-foot tanker he commanded, one of the newest and most advanced in Exxon's fleet of oil cargo carriers, grounded on Bligh Reef in the early morning hours of March 24. The holes gashed in its giant tanks caused the nation's worst oil spill, a gusher of 10.92 million gallons of oil spurting into the crystal waters of Prince William Sound. Countless birds, fish and wildlife perished and hundreds of miles of rocky shore was blackened. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is charged with felony criminal mischief and three misdemeanors _ reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. If convicted he could face a maximum of 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. At his trial, a procession of 23 prosecution witnesses have given accounts of the disaster and its possible causes. Testimony has focused on Hazelwood's alleged intoxication and his behavior as commander of the ship. Key points of inquiry have been: _ Was Hazelwood drunk? Crew members say he neither slurred nor staggered and was cool and calm in the wake of the accident. But blood and urine tests taken nearly 10 hours after the accident showed alcohol in his system, and he was seen drinking in a Valdez bar earlier in the day. _ Did Hazelwood act recklessly when he left the bridge of his ship in the hands of the third mate and a helmsman during a tricky maneuver past ice? Witnesses say Hazelwood knew the helmsman needed close supervision, even when doing simple tasks. The veteran third mate, Gregory Cousins, said he agreed to take charge of the ship while Hazelwood went below for a few minutes. _ Was Hazelwood trying to steer his ship off the reef after the accident? Witnesses have said that backing the tanker off the reef might have caused it to capsize, adding loss of life to the tragedy. But Hazelwood's lawyers say he never reversed gears and ultimately stabilized the ship on the reef. In a tape played for jurors, the skipper tells the Coast Guard: ``We are working our way off the reef.'' _ Did Hazelwood endanger the crew by not sounding a general alarm or abandoning ship after the grounding? The prosecution says he should have awakened everyone and possibly gotten them into lifboats. The chief mate testified that Hazelwood acted prudently and would have taken greater risks putting people into the choppy waters of Prince William Sound in the middle of the night. Experts in maritime affairs may give their opinions of Hazelwood's decisions. And specialists in the study of alcoholism will give opinions on whether he was intoxicated. The range of experts who may testify was indicated Friday when Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole disclosed he had discovered some new witnesses he wanted to call. The defense protested it was too late to come up with new experts and the judge said he might not grant permission for their appearance but took the matter under consideration. The experts are said to be able to determine from tape-recorded voices whether a person is drunk. They would be asked to analyze the tapes played for jurors of Hazelwood's conversations with Coast Guard monitors moments after his ship ran onto the reef. The skipper spoke slowly and in a deep, gravelly voice as he announced the disaster, saying, ``We've fetched up hard aground ... evidently leaking some oil. We're going to be here for a while.'' Was that his normal voice? Crew members said that was how he spoke all the time and certainly how he sounded earlier in the day. Prosecutors are trying to prove that he sounded intoxicated. The trial was in recess for the Presidents Day holiday and was to resume Tuesday.

DOC.SECOND: 69-Year-Old Musher Finishes Race To The Sky
DOC.TEXT: The faithful and the curious came out to watch a 69-year-old musher cross the finish line of the 540-mile Race to the Sky, a sled dog run that had beaten him on four previous tries. David Armstrong was the last of the finishers Saturday, but he finished. Seven others of the 15 starters already had dropped out. ``I do it because I still can,'' Armstrong said in Lincoln, the last checkpoint before the finish line and, until Saturday, the farthest he had gone in the race. ``And as long as I can, I guess I will.'' Led by 10 sled dogs and cheered on by scores of supporters, Armstrong, of Helena, crossed the finish line to officially place eighth. Alaskan Dean Osmar shattered the course record Thursday, winning in 120 hours 9 minutes. Armstrong, who began racing sled dogs in New Hampshire in 1937 and helped establish long-distance racing in Montana, was officially clocked at 164 hours and 39 minutes to conclude the race at Dog Creek, near the Continential Divide west of Helena. The 5th annual race began south of Helena a week before, retracing most of the same ground. While Saturday's final chapter took place in Dog Creek, the story began to unfold 89 miles away in Lincoln where Armstrong realized he was going to be able to finish his first 500-mile dog race. ``It's become more of an emotional thing,'' Armstrong said. ``The feeling is totally different. I guess it's because we've never finished before. ``It's a little bit of stubbornness in me. But overall, I'd say it's a culmination of five tries. ``I guess I was optimistic about finally making it,'' he said. ``It means a lot. I have three dogs that have raced with me all five years. It's just a team effort.''

DOC.HEAD: Party to Celebrate Incorporation Mistakenly Planned Outside New City
DOC.TEXT: A party to celebrate the incorporation of this suburb between Seattle and Tacoma will be held outside the municipal boundaries, embarassed organizers have learned. Only after scheduling arranging the bash at the Sportsworld bowling alley complex did planners learn that it was not within the municipality approved by voters a year ago, said organizer Mary Ehlis. ``We thought it was in the city because the border is right there,'' she said. ``Then I got one of the new maps that came out, and I went, `Ohhhhh ...' I couldn't believe it. It's just a fraction out, but it is out.'' The Feb. 28 party is the main celebration on the first day of cityhood for Federal Way, population about 58,000. Other events include noting the delivery of the city's first baby at St. Francis Community Hospital, unveiling the first City Hall sign and sealing a 50-year time capsule _ all within the city limits.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Weak Power Base, Kaifu Leads Party to Majority
With AM-Japan-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is youthful, eloquent and witty. Although untainted by recent political scandals, he has little power base of his own in the governing Liberal Democratic Party. In short, he is everything that party power brokers were looking for last August after the Liberal Democrats lost their majority in Parliament's upper house and scandals forced two prime ministers from office. Kaifu, who reportedly owns thousands of polka-dot neckties, is a member of the smallest faction in the governing party. His elevation to prime minister last year at age 58 fulfilled a prophecy he made 29 years earlier, at the age of 29. Not surprisingly, he regards 29 as his lucky number. Other political seers, however, forecast a short stay for the confident politician from Aichi prefecture in central Japan, about 170 miles west of Tokyo. The opposition quickly branded him a puppet of former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, who was forced to resign last year after charges he had received more than $1 million in donations and loans from the Recruit Co., the company at the center of a massive scandal that plagued Japanese politics for much of the past year. Political analysts predicted Kaifu would remain in power just long enough for the Liberal Democrats to regroup and cleanse their scandal-tainted image. That fate may still await him. Powerful men like former Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe, who was re-elected Sunday despite ties to the Recruit scandal, reportedly aspire to replace him. While Kaifu was in Eastern Europe in January, Abe overshadowed him by leading a delegation to the Soviet Union to meet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. And Kaifu reportedly has been excluded from recent key party decisions, including the timing of Sunday's election. But while Kaifu has not pursued an independent line or made much concrete progress in promised party reforms, he has proven a credible and attractive leader to the public. Kaifu, a former education minister, was first elected to Parliament at the age of 29, when he was sent to the House of Representatives by the third district of Aichi prefecture. He became a protege of the late Prime Minister Takeo Miki, a reformer who led the party out of a Lockheed payoff scandal in the mid-1970s. Miki's faction evolved into the present Komoto faction, to which Kaifu belongs. A graduate of Waseda University, the alma mater of many Liberal Democratic politicians, Kaifu was a member of the debate club. Kaifu has two children, and until he became prime minister regularly jogged in the morning with his wife.

DOC.HEAD: Doi Shakes Up World of Conservative, Male-Dominated Politics
With AM-Japan-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In her three years as chairwoman of the Japan Socialist Party, Takako Doi has shaken up the staid world of Japanese politics and along the way become a widely admired figure. Ms. Doi, a 61-year-old former law professor, brought her party into serious contention for power last summer when she led an election campaign that stripped the long-ruling Liberal Democrats of their majority in the upper house of Parliament and boosted the Socialists' standing. Her exhortative stumping style, so out of keeping with the meek image commonly projected by most Japanese women, galvanized female voters. Along with other disgruntled members of the electorate, it was female voters who ushered a record 17 women _ 10 of them Socialists _ into the 252-seat upper house. Japanese media dubbed the phenomenon ``Madonna power.'' Again in Sunday's lower house election, the Socialists gained strength at the expense of other parties, chipping away at the Liberal Democrats' single-party domination of Japanese politics. ``This election shows that Japan's political party system has matured some,'' said Takehiko Kamo, professor of political science at Tokyo University. ``Under Ms. Doi's leadership, the Socialists are becoming more mature.'' Ms. Doi was born Nov. 30, 1928, in Japan's major port city of Kobe, 270 miles west of Tokyo. The daughter of a physician, she was educated at a Kobe girls' school and later in Kyoto, the ancient capital of Japan. There, in 1949, she entered Doshisha University's law department. She attracted notice as a ferocious cheerleader for the rugby squad and as an actress in a college Shakespeare production. After graduating in 1951, she was made a research fellow at Doshisha, and later a law professor. She remained unmarried. A specialist in Japan's constitution, she became involved in politics in the 1960s, and in 1969 was elected to the House of Representatives from the 2nd District of Hyogo prefecture, near Kobe. She became party vice chairwoman in 1983, and its leader on Sept. 8, 1986, the first woman to head a major political party in modern Japan. An entry in ``Who's Who in Japan'' lists piano and music appreciation as her hobbies, but the popular press says pachinko, a Japanese pinball game, rates higher with her.

DOC.HEAD: Global Warming Can Be Sloved at a Profit
DOC.TEXT: Improving energy efficiency using today's technology can solve the global warming problem at a profit of a trillion dollars a year, a study says. A push for energy efficiency would reduce the use of coal and other fossil fuels that is raising carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere, said the study's author, Amory Lovins of the Rocky Mountain Institute in Snowmass, Colo. ``Why fiddle while coal burns? We ought to get on with it,'' Lovins said Sunday at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. The trillion dollars that could be saved each year is equal to the global military budget, Lovins said. Saving energy is far more profitable than building new power plants, he said. Indeed, energy efficiency is so profitable that it ought to be encouraged even if there were no threat of global warming from the increased atmospheric carbon dioxide, he said. ``It doesn't matter how the scientific evidence is shaking out (on the severity of global warming), because we ought to do the same thing anyway,'' Lovins said. Lovins is an economist and consultant who has been arguing since the mid-1970s for greater energy efficiency. He has been criticized by the utility industry and others who say that energy efficiency of the degree that he is calling for cannot be practically achieved. Lovins has worked hard to support the argument that very large improvements in energy efficiency can be made using current technology. He cited a study last year by the Swedish State Power Board which found that over the next 20 years Sweden could expand its economy by 50 percent, reduce carbon dioxide output by one-third and lower utility bills _ all through the use of increased energy efficiency. That includes the voter-mandated elimination by 2010 of nuclear power, which currently supplies half of Sweden's electricity. In the United States, Lovins has calculated that one-fourth of U.S. electricity output could be saved with more efficient lighting, one-fourth with efficient motors, and one-fourth in appliances and other equipment. One problem is that there is no agency to review and redesign a manufacturer's use of motors, for example. The technology exists, but the infrastructure to make it available doesn't, Lovins said. Furthermore, utility planners, policy-makers and politicians are not aware of the potential for savings, he said. Lovins and his colleagues have done a study to show the promise of savings using currently available energy-saving technology. They found that a world of 8 billion people with an economy five times the size of the current one could be supported with only one-third of the energy used today. ``Energy policy built on efficiency would enable the earth to support a prosperous civilization that was not plagued by acid rain, global warming, urban smog, nuclear proliferation and deforestation,'' the study concluded. Among the schemes Lovins has devised are programs in which fees and rebates are used to promote efficiency. For example, fees for hooking up new buildings to utility lines could be raised for buildings that use energy inefficiently, and rebates could be given to energy-efficient buildings. The same kind of sliding scale could be used for cars, with fees charged for gas-guzzlers and rebates offered for energy-efficient vehicles.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopter Base Falls to Aoun Rivals; Cease-Fire Called
LaserPhoto BEI2
DOC.TEXT: The Red Cross evacuated 500 commandos of renegade Gen. Michel Aoun's army from a helicopter base Sunday after it fell to the rival Lebanese Forces militia. The evacuation was possible after Aoun and rival Christian warlord Samir Geagea called a cease-fire Saturday night to halt their murderous struggle for control of Lebanon's Christian enclave. Police said 30 combatants were killed and 42 wounded in the fighting that preceded the fall of the Adma helicopter base to Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia. The base was Aoun's only major foothold in Kesrouan province, a Geagea stronghold. With Adma's fall, Geagea now controls nearly two-thirds of the Christian enclave, plus all its ports. Aoun has no harbor equipped to receive ships and is expected to demand the withdrawal of the Lebanese Forces from Beirut's port as a condition for a durable peace. ``Otherwise, the cease-fire will be short,'' said a police spokesman. Aoun's command reported the deaths of 10 soldiers in combat during the past two days. That raised the overall toll to 660 killed and 1,872 wounded in 18 days of fighting between Aoun's 19,000 troops and Geagea's 6,000-strong militia, which has 30,000 reservists. More than 100,000 residents, one-tenth of the enclave's population, fled to Syrian-policed Moslem zones, and material losses were estimated at $750 million. It was the worst confrontation between Christians since Lebanon's civil war between Christians and Moslems broke out in 1975. Shells tore through schools and churches and apartments collapsed on their residents. Hospitals were packed with casualties. Thousands of cars and hundreds of shops were gutted. Power plants and water pumping plants came to a standstill on the first day of the fighting, leaving the Lebanese capital and its environs without electricity and running water for nearly three weeks. Police reported only scattered gunfire Sunday. The truce was the 12th called since the clashes erupted Jan. 30. ``It looks like this one might hold,'' said the police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing rules. ``Both sides have pledged strict adherence and the evacuation of the Adma base is an encouraging start.'' Aoun conceded Adma's loss. In an interview broadcast by his Radio Lebanon station, he said the negotiated evacuation of the garrison was an ``indicator pointing to a possible political settlement, but not part of a settlement.'' An estimated 1,500 Lebanese Forces militiamen with 20 T-54 tanks and 40 armored personnel carriers closed in on the hilltop base from three directions Saturday. After 12 hours of fighting, Aoun agreed to a cease-fire on condition of a ``dignified evacuation of his 500 commandos with all their weapons,'' said the police spokesman. They rolled out from Adma in four U.S.-built M-48 tanks, 25 armored personnel carriers and 12 Red Cross buses starting at midnight Saturday, leaving behind 12 helicopter gunships. Lebanese Forces militiamen then moved in to take over the base. The convoy of Aoun's commandos climbed through the Kesrouan highway to a mountain ridge and crossed into the Aoun-held Metn province early Sunday, the spokesman reported. ``The operation was completed without a hitch,'' said Shaker Abu Suleiman, a member of a three-man mediation committee representing Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir, spiritual head of the dominant Maronite Catholic community. ``A massacre in Adma has been averted.'' Geagea attacked Adma after Aoun's forces defeated the Lebanese Forces in their main stronghold of east Beirut, Ein Rummaneh. That left Geagea and his fighters trapped in the city's Ashrafiyeh residential district and the neighboring Karantina quarter with their backs to the sea. ``Aoun's army can move in against them any time, but it will be another horrendous massacre. Geagea is bent on a scorched-earth resistance, and his fighters have mined all approaches to the two districts,'' the police spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Bennett: Some Type of `Death Penalty' for Bankers Who Launder Drug Money
DOC.TEXT: Drug policy director William Bennett said Sunday he would support ``something analogous'' to the death penalty for high-level bankers who launder drug money. Bennett has said he supports the death penalty for convicted drug kingpins and, in an appearance on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program, he said bankers who knowingly handle drug cash should be treated similarly. ``If we're talking about capital punishment for people who are high-level drug dealers, we ought to be talking about something analogous for the high-level banker who trades in drug cash,'' he said. President Bush's proposed drug control strategy calls for expanding the circumstances under which convicted drug kingpins could face the death penalty. Bennett's comment came during questioning about a case in which the Luxembourg-based Bank of Credit and Commerce International pleaded guilty in January to cocaine-related money-laundering charges and agreed to forfeit $14 million and to help prosecutors who say the case has ties to deposed Panamanian leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Bennett indicated he was concerned that the sentence was light and said he raised that concern with Bush ``and he agreed.'' But asked whether he was troubled that the bank was still in business, he said, ``Not until the story's over. I want to see where the investigation comes out.'' He said the case is part of an ongoing investigation and that he and other officials will continue to monitor it. Bennett also said he hopes for greater military cooperation between the United States and South America's cocaine-producing countries to stop the flow of illegal drugs. ``Will there be cooperation between Colombia and the United States, other countries and the United States involving military cooperation?'' he said. ``I think there will be.'' He added: ``I would not be surprised if in the future we have discussions with President Barco (of Colombia) and other presidents about the ways in which U.S. military intelligence ... can be useful to them. ... ``They asked for our help last year, and if they ask for our help again, we'll be interested in providing it,'' he said. The United States has been providing aid to Colombia, Peru and Bolivia to help those countries cut off drug production and stop trafficking to the United States. Bush, at the drug summit in Cartagena, Colombia, last week signed a communique with Barco and the presidents of Peru and Bolivia that rules out the use of U.S. military forces in those countries but encourages cooperation and intelligence-sharing. The United States also agreed to provide increased equipment and training to the law enforcement agencies and armed forces of the other countries.

DOC.HEAD: One Prisoner Killed, Another Hurt in Helicopter Escape Attempt
DOC.TEXT: One convict was killed and another seriously injured in an escape attempt Sunday when a rope that was lowered into their prison yard by a helicopter broke, the government said. The rope got tangled in cables that had been laid above the prison yard to prevent such escapes, officials at the Justice Ministry said. The prisoners' three accomplices in the helicopter escaped, according to the ministry officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Emile Dieudonne, 38, died after falling 25 feet to the exercise yard at the Fresnes prison in suburban Paris. Fernando Alonso de Celada of Argentina, also 38, suffered multiple fractures but his life was not in danger, officials said. It was not clear whether the two men collaborated in the escape attempt. An inidentified man later telephoned the French news agency Agence France-Presse and said he had participated in the attempt. He said it had been organized for Dieudonne alone. AFP said Alonso de Celada grabbed onto Dieudonne's legs as the helicopter started to rise and that Dieudonne tried to kick the other prisoner away before the rope snapped. Authorities said three unidentified men rented the Alouette III helicopter from an agency in nearby Issy-Les-Moulineaux and pulled guns on the pilot after they were airborne. The pilot was ordered to head for the Fresnes prison and to hover above the prison yard, where about 20 inmates were exercising. A steel-centered, nylon, mountain-climbing rope was lowered through the grill of cables above the prison yard. Dieudonne and Alonso de Celada grabbed the rope and the helicopter started to fly away. But the rope apparently caught on the grillwork and snapped, officials said. The armed trio then ordered the pilot to land at an empty sports stadium, where they drove off in a car and remained at large Sunday night. Dieudonne, a convicted robber, began serving a 12-year sentence in 1984. Alonso de Celada is serving a life term for two murders and 20 assaults.

DOC.HEAD: High-Profile Hightower Draws Fire, Opponents
DOC.TEXT: For a guy holding a low-ranking state office, Texas Agriculture Commissioner Jim Hightower enjoys a high profile. Democrats put him on their national convention podium. President Bush's son endorsed one of his Republican rivals. GOP lawmakers tried to abolish his job. The Texas Farm Bureau tried and failed to get Texas Rangers pitcher Nolan Ryan to run as a Republican against him, then sponsored six farmers to challenge him in the Democratic primary March 13. He's even been blamed for the coming invasion of killer bees. Through it all, Hightower has kept his trademark sense of humor. ``There's an old East Texas saying that a lie is halfway around the world before the truth can get its boots on. We're getting our boots on early because they're going to be telling a lot of lies,'' he said. After reports of an apparently bogus news release being circulated that blamed Hightower for failing to stop killer bees moving north from Central America, he quipped, ``I'm going to have to start wearing pest strip on my lapel as I go around, just to get through this election.'' Other criticism has been more serious. Republicans and conservative Democrats have accused the self-proclaimed populist of using the agriculture job to promote his own political future rather than the work of Texas farmers and ranchers. The Dallas Morning News said last week that $6,600 in contributions were made to Hightower's campaign by seed and grain dealers after they were visited by an agriculture department employee who was accompanied by a consultant soliciting for the campaign. Hightower denies knowing about the solicitations. Adopting the nickname ``Whole Hog,'' Hightower was elected in 1982. He quickly became a Democratic spokesman against President Reagan's farm policies with such lines as, ``Reagan's idea of a good farm program is `Hee Haw.''' He was one of the few white politicians to back Jesse Jackson's 1988 presidential bid and talked of challenging Republican U.S. Sen. Phil Gramm this year. Instead, he opted to seek a third four-year term, saying he wants to keep pushing innovative economic development efforts that include alternative crops and direct marketing. His department has encouraged farmers to plant everything from Christmas trees to wine grapes. It started a ``Taste of Texas'' national promotion to help small producers sell everything from smoked sausage to hot sauce. It helped Panhandle grain farmers start a flour mill. ``It's a philosophy of economic development at the grass-roots level,'' he said. ``We've been able to turn loose the enterprise of, really, thousands of Texas producers in a way that demonstrates that this new agricultural model actually works.'' But he made enemies, too. When the U.S. Department of Agriculture balked over European demands for beef free of artificial growth hormones, Hightower moved to establish a state program to certify such meat. That brought cries from the White House and the Texas Farm Bureau, which charged that he was giving credibility to what they consider false fears about hormones and making traditional ranchers look bad. Hightower's aggressive stance on pesticide regulation won praise from farm workers. It also brought efforts to turn his elected job into an appointive one. Conservative legislators lost that battle, but they did create a new pesticide regulation board on which Hightower is but one member of nine. Looking for a big name to go against Hightower, Republicans urged former Dallas Cowboys running back Walt Garrison to run. The Farm Bureau sought Ryan. Neither took up the challenge. When Republican state Rep. Rick Perry entered the race, Hightower replied, ``I thought they were talking about Gaylord Perry,'' the retired pitcher. Other Republican hopefuls are Gene Duke, a cotton seed businessman, and consultant Richard McIver. All six Democratic primary challengers are farmers or ranchers who paid their $3,000 filing fees with contributions from the Farm Bureau's political arm. They are Neal Burnett, Dan Pustejovsky, Dan Krenek, John Earl Smith, Paul McDaniel and Clyde Chandler. ``The incumbent commissioner has no practical farming or ranching experience,'' said Farm Bureau official Vernie Glasson. ``As we see it today, it is an anybody but the incumbent campaign.'' ``Antelope meat and Christmas trees (are) well and good,'' said Chandler. ``But while you spend all your money, time and energy on these small, insignificant amount of crops, the mainstream agriculture is suffering.'' ``Texas farmers and ranchers deserve to have one of their own as agriculture commissioner,'' said Perry, a former Democrat who expects to raise $2 million to $3 million for the race. ``Hightower spent an inordinate amount of time in 1987 and 1988 outside Texas, campaigning for Jesse Jackson and Mike Dukakis and preparing to run himself against Sen. Phil Gramm. Those were not the activities Texans had in mind for their agriculture commissioner,'' Perry said. Hightower says the race is a referendum on the department's future. ``We've carved out a pretty clear identity, I think, in the public mind,'' he said. ``Basically all I've heard from the folks who are running against me is that I'm a friend of Jane Fonda.''

DOC.HEAD: Fans of Prince Charles Fighting for Tickets to Washington Dinner Speech
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7th graf, Before his, and 11th graf, Bush plans, to CORRECT day of week to Thursday
DOC.TEXT: Fresh from playing polo in Florida, Prince Charles is flying into town this week to indulge in his other favorite sport _ architect-bashing _ and American architects are falling over themselves for the chance to be abused. Disappointed fans are still fighting over nonexistent tickets to Thursday night's black-tie gala of the American Institute of Architects, where the 41-year-old heir to the British throne and outspoken critic of contemporary architecture will be the main attraction. ``We've been sold out for a month,'' institute Vice President Gregg Ward said, adding that there was a lengthy waiting list. ``People have been calling my boss, the British Embassy, the White House, even Buckingham Palace trying to get in.'' Among AIA's membership ``Certainly the interest has been extraordinary since we announced that Prince Charles was coming,'' Ward said. When callers are told that all 1,200 seats for the $250-a-plate dinner at the National Building Museum had been snapped up, he said, ``some have expressed disappointment, some have been on the verge of tears, some have been in a rage.'' The future British king was expected to pay President Bush a courtesy call at the White House before the dinner. They last met during Charles' low-key visit to Washington one year ago, when he had afternoon tea with Vice President Dan Quayle and dinner with Bush at Camp David, Md. Before his dinner audience of leading U.S. architects, members of Congress, Supreme Court justices, diplomats and Hollywood celebrities Thursday night, Charles will have a new opportunity to express his disdain for modern architecture. In the past, he has stirred controversy by saying London's skyline has suffered more damage from architects, city planners and developers than from German bombers in World War II. He says some of the city's new buildings remind him of word processors and nuclear power stations. In ``A Vision of Britain,'' an award-winning book he published last year, Charles said some modern architects have created ``Frankenstein monsters, devoid of character, alien and largely unloved except by the professors who have been concocting these horrors in their laboratories.'' During the AIA's five-day ``Accent on Architecture'' conference this week, leading U.S. architects will debate Charles' call for building designs that respect the surrounding landscape and are scaled to human proportions and needs. Bush plans to present the AIA's Gold Medal _ its highest honor _ to Fayetteville, Ark., architect Fay Jones, a former pupil of Frank Lloyd Wright, at a White House ceremony Thursday. Jones will be a guest of honor at the dinner where Charles will speak. Charles also will preside at the ceremonial opening of an AIA exhibit of 120 original drawings, models, paintings, manuscripts and artifacts from Sir Christopher Wren's design and construction of St. Paul's Cathedral in London. Charles and his wife, Diana, who is not accompanying him on his current tour, were married in St. Paul's in 1981. The prince's busy schedule also included an embassy reception for the alumni association of Marshall Scholars, a British government program under which 30 exceptional American students are selected annually to spend two or three years at British universities. Charles' itinerary included his arrival in Vero Beach, Fla., Friday to play in two charity polo matches over four days. He was traveling to Washington via Charleston, S.C., where he will attend an international business conference sponsored by his ``Business in the Community'' program, which seeks to enlist corporations in the revitalization of local communities.

DOC.HEAD: Sharon Resigns, Says He Will Challenge Shamir
LaserPhoto TLV2
DOC.TEXT: Ariel Sharon, leader of the far-right wing of the Likud bloc, resigned from the Cabinet Sunday and said he would campaign to topple Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and replace the government peace plan with his own. Sharon said he decided to resign because he felt the government's plan made too many concessions to the Arabs and could lead to war. ``The plan by itself is a mistake. It will not bring us peace, but will lead to more tension and more bloodshed and maybe even to a war which all of us would like to prevent,'' Sharon said. The 62-year-old conservative, who as defense minister masterminded Israel's 1982 Lebanon invasion, is Shamir's chief rival in the right-wing Likud bloc. He has repeatedly argued that Shamir's plan, which calls for Palestinian elections and negotiations on a limited autonomy in the occupied lands, could bring the PLO into the peace process. He fears it could lead to Israel's relinquishing the West Bank and Gaza Strip, captured during the 1967 Middle East war. Sharon, the trade minister, first announced his resignation at a tumultuous Likud meeting last week. He made it official at the weekly Cabinet session Sunday. By law, the resignation is effective after 48 hours. Sharon still retains his key post of chairing Likud's ruling Central Committee. He said he plans to take his campaign to the people to win support. Asked if he would challenge Shamir's leadership of the Likud, Sharon said: ``The answer is yes.'' Likud shares power with the center-left Labor Party, which favors compromise and giving up some land for peace. In 1984, Sharon challenged Shamir for the leadership of Likud following the resignation of Menachem Begin. He told reporters he then received 42 percent of the vote. Polls taken before last week's Likud meeting showed Shamir ahead by 63 percent to 78 percent. Speaking to reporters in his Jerusalem office after resigning, Sharon said he would fight to replace Shamir's plan, which was ratified by the Cabinet last May, with one of his own. He said his plan would involve opening the border with Jordan and creating housing projects for Palestinian refugees in the occupied territories to reduce tensions. The former general also said that the Arab uprising in the territories, now in its 27th month, would have to be crushed before peace talks can begin. In the latest fatality of the uprising, a 17-year old Palestinian girl was fatally wounded Sunday during a stone-throwing clash with soldiers and Israeli settlers in the West Bank city of Nablus, Arab reporters said. The army confirmed the death of the girl, Sawsan Shahshir, and said it was investigating. Sharon, a famous army commander still respected by many Israelis, has served in Israeli governments since 1977. As agriculture minister, Sharon led a controversial campaign to build Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza. The settlements are often cited by the United States as an obstacle to peace. In 1981, Sharon was appointed defense minister and directed the 1982 Lebanon invasion that led to an unpopular three-year occupation. He was forced to resign as defense minister in 1983 when an Israeli inquiry found him indirectly responsible for the massacre of hundreds of Palestinians by Israel's Lebanese militia allies in Beirut's refugee camps. But he stayed in the Cabinet as a minister without portfolio and has served as trade minister and a member of the decision-making Inner Cabinet since 1984. Also Sunday, Israeli troops shot and wounded 10 Palestinians in a stone-throwing clash in the Gaza Strip town of Rafah, Arab reports said. The bodies of two Palestinian men were found near Nablus, but the motives behind their murders could not be immediately determined. During the uprising, Palestinians have killed at least 186 fellow Arabs on suspicion of assisting Israeli authorities. At least 657 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli troops or civilians, and 43 Israelis have been killed.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Trace Negative Portrayals Of Blacks In Popular Culture
DOC.TEXT: After Willie Horton attacked a white couple while on furlough from a state prison, George Bush's campaign aides used his image as a potent political weapon. When Charles Stuart plotted the killing of his wife, as police have come to believe, he thought he could convince an entire city that a black man had committed the crime. And he nearly succeeded in doing so for more than two months. Both cases tapped into white fears and the stereotype of a ruthless, marauding black man, even though Horton's furlough was one of many and Carol Stuart was much more likely to be killed by her husband than by a black stranger. Researchers and civil libertarians say the images of American blacks, once obviously racist portrayals of blacks as dim-witted, carefree or dangerous, are more subtle these days _ but no less persuasive or damaging. ``There's no question race is being used more often as a political tool,'' said Harvard University law professor Alan Dershowitz. ``Race is used and exploited in politics. It corresponds to people's fears, and it's being used on both sides.'' Patricia Turner, a professor of black studies at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, traces negative portrayals of blacks in popular culture since before the Civil War. ``Back then, blacks were shown as docile and contented, simple people who weren't really up to the demands of the white world,'' Turner says. ``They were seen as people who danced and sang all night, and then were too tired to get up for work the next morning.'' This ``dancing darkie'' image alternated with the Uncle Tom, the benevolent, kindly old black man, Turner said. But the fear associated with Willie Horton is rooted in an image that gained currency after the Civil War. This was the ``buck,'' an aggressive, hostile young black man seen as wanting to molest white women. ``Often, the buck was dressed in black, and carried some sort of razor or knife, and was set in juxtaposition to a white woman,'' Turner said. Charles Stuart said his assailant was a black man in a black jogging suit, noted Turner, who helped research ``Ethnic Notions,'' a public televison documentary on the distorted image of blacks in American popular culture. The film shows a scene from D.W. Griffith's 1915 silent movie, ``Birth of a Nation,'' in which a white actor in blackface menaces a young white woman. Instead of letting herself be raped, she jumps from a cliff to her death. The buck image resurfaced whenever whites felt threatened by blacks: after the abolition of slavery, after World War I when returning black soldiers had heightened expectations of their place in American society, and during the civil rights movement of the 1960s. The images, though unreal, had very real consequences. ``One of the main reasons black men were lynched was that white men thought they wanted to rape white women,'' said Dr. Alvin Poussaint, a Harvard Medical School psychiatrist. ``That's been a white American preoccupation.'' In the 1988 presidential battle between George Bush and Gov. Michael Dukakis, a Bush TV commercial showed a mug shot of a glowering Horton and implied Dukakis supported freeing convicted murderers for weekend furloughs. Critics said the commercials incited racial fears among whites and played on racist attitudes and biases. Last year, Stuart's account of being attacked by a black man used invoked the same negative racial image, and his account led police to stop and search black males in Boston's inner city. ``Race was used in both cases as a political tool,'' said state Rep. Byron Rushing of Boston, a black lawmaker. ``The idea of the negative black icon is so well known, people can only use it in a cold and calculated manner. It's not a matter of someone saying `oops.''' ``The president rode Willie Horton into the White House. It wasn't relevant to his ability to lead,'' said Louis Elisa, president of the Boston chapter of the NAACP. ``Race has become the easiest way to pass on fear.''

DOC.HEAD: Boston Archbishop Leaves for Cuba Trip
DOC.TEXT: Archbishop Cardinal Bernard Law, departing Sunday for a three-day visit to Cuba, said he consulted with President Bush about recent hints at reform dropped by Cuba's Communist Party. ``The president is very interested in what my impressions will be of this trip,'' said Law, who spoke with Bush on Saturday. The Roman Catholic prelate has formed a strong friendship with the president in recent years. Law, who is scheduled to meet with Cuban Archbishop Jaime Ortega and other Cuban bishops on Tuesday, said he would welcome the chance to meet with Cuban leader Fidel Castro, but no meeting between them is planned. Law's departure came a day after Cuba's hard-line Communist party called for a party congress next year and hinted that it might consider some political and economic reforms. ``Obviously, a change would benefit everyone,'' Law said. ``For them to develop some kind of rhetorical diversity would be very significant.'' Law met with Castro on previous trips to Cuba in 1985 and 1989, and while he said no meeting was scheduled with the Cuban leader this time around, he would welcome the chance to have one. Law said the trip's main purpose was to strengthen ties between the Catholic Church in the United States and in Cuba. More than 40 percent of Cuba's 10 million people are Catholic. Castro has been one of the Communist world's staunchest holdouts and has criticized the democratic reforms that have swept out Old Guard Communist leaders in Eastern Europe over the past year. On Jan. 28, Castro that Cuba would stick to orthodox Communism even if its longtime ally, the Soviet Union, cut off $5 billion a year in aid.

DOC.HEAD: Ranking ANC Leader Appeals To Whites For Support
DOC.TEXT: A top-ranking exiled leader of the African National Congress, in an unprecedented interview shown Sunday on state-run television, appealed to whites to help build a post-apartheid South Africa. Thabo Mbeki, the ANC's equivalent of a foreign minister, told viewers they had been the victims of a prolonged misinformation campaign that depicted his organization as seeking to impose a communist-style one-party state. ``What has inspired the ANC for all these 70-plus years of its existence has been the vision of a South Africa that belongs to all the people,'' Mbeki said from Lusaka, Zambia, the group's headquarters. ``If they acted together, they could transform this country into something great.'' It was the first time the South African Broadcasting Corp. has conducted and broadcast its own in-depth interview with one of the ANC's exiled leaders. On Thursday, it carried an interview by two of its reporters with Nelson Mandela, the ANC leader freed Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison. Until Feb. 2, when President F.W. de Klerk lifted a 30-year ban on the ANC, it was a crime for South African media to quote Mbeki and other senior ANC leaders. Asked about de Klerk's peace initiative, aimed at starting negotiations on a new constitution, Mbeki replied: ``The road ahead is still a long road, with lots of problems in front of us. But hopefully the doors to a political settlement of this problem have been opened.'' ``What white South Africa needs to do is to join the process of ending the apartheid system,'' he said. ``Presumably these people who acted together to change the past would have confidence enough in one another to build the future.'' He said whites have ``a very, very wrong perception of the ANC, the result of many decades of misinformation ... that the ANC is some communist-dominated group whose intention is to impose itself on the people of South Africa with a one-party state, that it's going to destroy the economy.'' ``It is important that the ANC should not be demonized in the eyes of the people,'' Mbeki said. He said he was not surprised at a backlash among right-wing whites opposed to de Klerk's reforms. ``A lot of white South Africans like the idea of political power being monopolized by the whites,'' he said. ``It is important that this small minority should not be given a right of veto, not be treated as a force to block change which the overwhelming majority of our people want.'' He said conservative whites ``need to be convinced that they as individuals, as families, will be better off in a situation where they don't have to be guarding their houses with guard dogs, arming themselves ... living in a situation of conflict and fear.'' On Friday, the ANC executive committee said in Lusaka it would send a delegation to South Africa for talks with de Klerk on how to remove obstacles to full negotiations on a new constitution. Mbeki is expected to be in the delegation, which will likely be joined by by Mandela and other ANC leaders based in South Africa. De Klerk has lifted bans on the ANC and other opposition groups, said political exiles can come home and made other concessions that met many of the ANC's pre-conditions for negotiations. The ANC is still demanding the lifting of the state of emergency, which has been in effect since June 1986, and the release of all political prisoners, including those convicted of acts of violence. De Klerk says the issue of prisoner releases could be a matter for negotiations, and there is speculation he might lift the emergency in exchange for a suspension of violence by the ANC. The ANC has waged a bombing and sabotage campaign since 1961 aimed at ending white-minority domination. There have been few attacks in the past year and the campaign has posed minimal military threat to the government.
