DOC.HEAD: Opposition Final Rally in Nicaragua Draws 60,000
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8th grafs to CLARIFY that rally is UNO's last of campaign but that it will continue media ads until Wednesday, the official end of the campaign; MOVES up reference to Sandinistas holding their last rally on Wednesday and DELETES last graf to conform. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MGA1
DOC.TEXT: The United National Opposition Sunday held the largest anti-government rally in 10 years, and its presidential candidate promised peace in Central America if she wins. Campaigning for next Sunday's general elections officially ends Wednesday, and it was UNO's last rally. The broad, U.S.-backed coalition of 14 parties and one native Indian organization _ known as UNO _ is the major rival of the ruling Sandinista National Liberation Front. ``On this bright day, which announces the end of the dark night of Sandinismo, I raise my flag of national reconciliation,'' Violeta Barrios de Chamorro told a crowd of about 60,000. Mrs. Chamorro repeated campaign promises to end the draft, rebuild the economy and reduce the size of the army, the largest in Central America. ``Next Sunday ... the vote of the people is going to knock down the wall of shame, as the German people did with the Berlin wall,'' she told cheering supporters at the Plaza of the Revolution. She is challenging President Daniel Ortega for a six-year term, in an election that has been called a referendum on 10 years of Sandinista rule. UNO is expected to run its media campaign until Wednesday, when the Sandinistas will hold their final rally. About 1.7 million Nicaraguans, nearly half of the population of 3.8 million, have registered to vote in the elections for president and vice president, National Assembly, 144 municipal councils and two regional councils. The rally drew the biggest opposition attendance yet. UNO complained, however, that officials refused to allow in a sound system rented in neighboring Costa Rica and that supporters coming from provincial towns were blocked or harassed. Police in riot gear had been stationed throughout Managua since Saturday night, and police jeeps with tear gas grenade-launchers were lined up on streets. Public transport was almost non-existent in the capital Sunday morning. Some people said they did not attend the rally because they feared trouble or had no way of getting there. ``They (police) stopped our caravan outside Masaya,'' a town 30 minutes from Managua, said one man at the rally, who would only give his first name, Santos. ``They kept us there for a long time, and people were getting angry. They finally let us go, but one truck at a time, very slowly.'' Mrs. Chamorro's running mate, Virgilio Godoy, spoke of 200,000 people at the rally, but international observers and journalists agreed on the estimate of 60,000. Mrs. Chamorro, publisher of the newspaper La Prensa, promised that Nicaragua's soldiers would be be trained for civilian jobs and none would be left unemployed, although the estimated 150,000-member armed forces would have to be slashed. ``And to my dear friends in Central America, I assure them that with the internal peace of Nicaragua, Central America also will have peace,'' she said. ``I will not allow a soldier to be made of each child,'' she said to wild cheers, alluding to the obligatory two-year military service for all boys age 16. ``Our democracy will have more teachers than soldiers, and many more schools than barracks.'' Mrs. Chamorro has little political experience, and is not rated as a good speaker; Sunday's address was considered her best. She was chosen to challenge Ortega largely for her symbolic value as the widow of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, a publisher and civic leader who was killed during the dictatorship of Anastasio Somoza and whose memory is revered by all in Nicaragua's political spectrum. Her right leg still in a cast because of a fractured knee, Mrs. Chamorro spoke from a raised stage while sitting in her wheelchair next to Godoy. In what was interpreted as a reply to Sandinista accusations that UNO is planning violent incidents to mar the elections, Mrs. Chamorro said: ``I urge all Nicaraguans to be calm so that next Sunday they go to vote and then go home, so as to avoid an incident.'' She said the best achievement of the campaign was that ``our country has overcome fear and has acquired a greater civic conscience.'' Godoy appealed to women voters, who make up 54 percent of registered voters. ``In the hands of the Nicaraguan woman ... is the future of the republic, and we know they won't leave it in this mess,'' Godoy said.

DOC.HEAD: J.C. Trewin, Doyen of London Theater Critics, Dies
DOC.TEXT: J.C. Trewin, doyen of London's theater critics and author of more than 50 books about the stage, has died at the age of 81, a hospital spokeswoman said Sunday. He died in the Royal Free Hospital in Hampstead, north London, on Friday. The hospital spokeswoman did not give the cause of death. For more than half a century Trewin covered the new plays on the London stage, becoming a respected and familiar figure at West End premieres. The son of a Cornish master mariner, John Courtenay Trewin fell in love with the theater as a child when ill health kept him from school and he taught himself to read with the aid of the family volume of Shakespeare's plays. He began his career as a journalist on the Western Independent Plymouth in 1926 and indulged his passion in the theater on trips to London, once recalling how in 1928 he saw Sir John Gielgud in his first starring role in the West End. Trewin joined the Morning Post in London in 1932 and became one of its theater critics two years later. He became known as the ``actors' critic'' because of his understanding of the art. He became literary editor of the Observer newspaper and in 1943 also was named its second theater critic alongside Ivor Brown. He held the position until 1953 and later was theater critic for numerous publications, among them Punch, The Lady and most recently, The Illustrated London News. Trewin's many books included ``Five and Eighty Hamlets,'' his description of the best of more than 150 major performances of the play he had witnessed in a lifetime in the theater. It was published in 1987. A stage historian, he lectured on Shakespeare, was a member of the Royal Society of Literature and was a former president of the Shakespeare Club of Stratford upon Avon. Trewin is survived by his wife, the former Wendy Monk, whom he married in 1938, and by two sons.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Charles Retains Polo Crown
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Prince Charles won both his polo match and the admiration of environmentalists Sunday in an afternoon that included a fund-raising event and an impromptu kiss from a former subject. The prince's Windsor Park polo team defeated White Birch 14-13 in sudden-death overtime to retain the Prince of Wales Cup at the Windsor Club polo grounds, about 10 miles north of Vero Beach. Before the match, the Prince of Wales addressed 580 guests at a $250-a-plate luncheon to benefit the Friends of Conservation, a group concerned with saving endangered East African animals. Among the nearly 3,000 spectators at the polo match were industrialist Armand Hammer and King Constantine of Greece, who is living in exile in the United Kingdom. The 40-year-old heir to the British throne didn't score in the match, but appeared in better form than during a game Friday, the first day of his week-long visit to the United States. The prince's team won the cup last year near Palm Beach. The polo match and lunch was expected to raise more than $200,000 for the Friends of Conservation, said event organizer Chrissy Kiely. The prince is the royal patron of the group, which has its U.S. offices in Oak Brook, Ill. At the luncheon, the prince spoke for about 10 minutes on several conservation efforts in East Africa, including anti-poaching measures and trade bans on ivory. The prince endorsed proposals to outlaw trade of ivory from elephant tusks. He also said the conservation organization has helped establish a camel-mounted anti-poaching patrol. The prince emphasized what he said was the need to rely on native Africans' knowledge to guide conservationists. ``We don't have a god-given right to modernize the ancient culture and wisdom of indigenous people,'' said the prince. ``It's particularly important now not to do anything with the ancient natural wisdom when we are most likely to need it.'' An auction after the speech included six place mats featuring copies of watercolor landscapes by the prince, which fetched $32,000 from Hammer. The sale of nine items raised $113,800, said Ms. Kiely. Before the luncheon, the prince viewed several wild animals brought in from the Cincinnati Zoo, including a baboon and a 95-pound aardvark that dug up the polo field with its powerful front claws. The prince, dressed in a plaid short-sleeve shirt, helped stomp the grass back into place. Jim Fowler, who appears on Mutual of Omaha's Wild Kingdom television show, drew a bemused look from the prince as he described how cheetahs were favored prey of the elite. ``They have been hunted by royalty since the beginning of mankind,'' he said. A baboon also apparently understood the significance of the occasion by smacking its lips. ``That's a sign of respect,'' said Fowler. As he was leaving, the prince also noticed a woman waving a British flag and beckoned her onto the field. She rushed forward, Union Jack and roses in hand, and gave the prince a long kiss on the cheek. The woman, Anita Littler, 45, a British emigre living in Miami, felt embarrassed by the display and left before the match, said organizer Marc Shafir. The prince is scheduled to visit the Kennedy Space Center on Monday and return to the home of friends Geoffrey and Jorie Kent, where he has stayed since Friday under tight security. The prince will attend a conference on international business on Tuesday and travel later in the week to Washington, D.C., where he will meet with President Bush and British Embassy officials.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Blames Social Problems for Unrest in Tadjikistan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT that unrest began in Dushanbe on Feb. 10, SUB 6th graf; pickup 7th graf pvs, `Mobs rampaged...'
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of people gathered Sunday in the Tadjikistan capital of Dushanbe to protest living conditions and a lack of consumer goods and medicines, Tass news agency reported. It said the crowd also decried further ethnic violence in the republic, where rioting in the last week has killed at least 22 people. Shodi Shabdolov, a secretary of the Tadjikistan Communist Party, blamed the violence on unresolved social problems, the party daily Pravda reported Sunday. He told Pravda one source of tension was that 117,000 young people had only seasonal jobs and an additional 70,000 were unemployed in Dushanbe, a city of 600,000 locate 1,600 miles southeast of Moscow. Shabdolov said riots had caused $12 million in damage and losses from looting amounted to $3.3 million more. The violence was touched off on Feb. 10 by rumors that Armenian refugees were arrving by the thousands and receiving scarce apartments in the city. Mobs rampaged through the tree-lined streets of Dushanbe, nestled at the foot of a high mountain range, and set fire to buildings, broke windows and smashed public vehicles. Tass said Sunday the situation remained unstable despite patrols by more than 7,000 regular police and Interior Ministry and army troops. It said protesters defied an official mourning period to hold rallies in two districts near Dushanbe and demand improved living standadrds. Tass said 61 people were arrested in the previous 24 houses for violating the state of emergency still in effect, and 44 pounds of narcotics were seized. Tadjikistan's Communist rulers offered to step down Wednesday because of the rioting, but their resignations were rejected Friday at an emergency session of the Central Committee, the party's policy-making body. In another dispatch, Tass said voters in the Central Asian republic of Uzbekistan complained of lack of choice in elections to the local legislature Sunday. It reported, ``Many voters said after voting that they struck out all candidates only due to the fact that they had no right of choice.'' Under Soviet voting rules, crossing out a candidate's name renders a ballot invalid. Uzbekistan has 10 million voters. Soviet leaders have said the goal for elections to local legislatures in many of the Soviet Union's 15 republics over the next six weeks was to have a choice among a range of candidates. The agency said the atmosphere in Uzbekistan was calm, despite earlier rumors that ethnic violence had broken out in the city of Samarkand Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Foundation Won't Give Medical Awards This Year
DOC.TEXT: The Lasker Medical Research Awards, often a precursor of the Nobel Prize, won't be awarded this year, an official said Sunday. Alice Fordyce, director of the awards program, said, ``The foundation has decided to make this first year of the '90s a sabbatical year for us, to review the whole program, our commitments, our priorities and our future objectives.'' The foundation has taken similar moratoriums in the past, she said. Since the first Lasker award was given in 1944, 49 Lasker winners have gone on to win the Nobel Prize.

DOC.HEAD: Trial to Begin For Man Charged in Teacher's Slaying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf to CORRECT to 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals sted District Court; SUBS final graf to DELETE redundant first reference to Porter. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Georgia Bombs
DOC.TEXT: A man accused in the abduction-slaying of a young preschool teacher is slated to go on trial Monday in a case linked to a spate of deadly mail bombings in the South. Emmanuel Hammond, 24, of Marietta is charged with felony murder, murder, kidnapping and armed robbery in the death of Julie Love, 27, whose 1988 disappearance sparked a search that lasted more than a year. Prosecutors plan to seek the death penalty if he is convicted. Hammond is black; Ms. Love is white. A letter claiming responsibility for the December mail bomb slayings cited Ms. Love's death and decried crimes by blacks against whites. Police allege that Hammond was the triggerman. His cousin, William Porter, pleaded guilty to murder and other charges in the case, and is expected to testify against him. Jury selection is to begin Monday in Fulton County Superior Court. Defense attorney William A. Wehunt has said the enormous publicity surrounding Ms. Love's disappearance and the discovery of her body could make selecting an impartial jury difficult. Wehunt, however, dropped an earlier effort to move the trial out of Fulton County, which includes most of Atlanta. The search that followed Ms. Love's disappearance in July 1988 included billboards and posters all over the Atlanta area bearing the message: ``Have You Seen Julie Love?'' Ms. Love's body was found in August in a wooded dumping ground in Atlanta, and Hammond was arrested that month. He is being held at the Fulton County jail without bond. The case drew renewed attention after Christmas when an Atlanta television station received the letter claiming responsibility for the mail-bomb deaths of a federal appeals Judge Robert Vance in Mountain Brook, Ala., and attorney Robert Robinson in Savannah. Similar bombs were intercepted at the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta, on which Vance served, and at the Jacksonville, Fla., office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Two small bombs exploded Saturday in grocery stores in Roswell about 20 miles north of Atlanta, but no one was injured and the city Police Chief Jerry King said the latest bombings didn't appear to be linked to the earlier ones. Fulton County authorities have promised heavy courtroom security for the Hammond trial, including extra sheriff's deputies to stand guard and daily searches by bomb-sniffing dogs. The trial was to have started Jan. 30, but was postponed because mental competence hearings for the defendant weren't completed in time. Hammond was found competent to stand trial, and Judge Ralph Hicks set a new date. Porter, 20, of Union City, who pleaded guilty in November to felony murder, rape, kidnapping and armed robbery, has yet to be sentenced.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Jews Demonstrate As Herzog Welcomes New Soviet Arrivals
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of Soviet Jews demonstrated in cold wind and pouring rain on Sunday to protest their living conditions even as President Chaim Herzog welcomed new arrivals. It was the first such protest since a mass Soviet Jewish immigration began last year. In 1989, about 12,000 Soviet Jews came to Israel. More than 8,000 have arrived so far this year, and Israel expects up to 100,000 Soviet Jews by year's end due to more liberal Soviet emigration policies, U.S. visa restrictions and rising anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union. The protesters gathered at Jerusalem's Gilo absorption center, the country's largest. They held signs reading, ``Until now you did not give me anything,'' and ``New immigrant, your debt to the Jewish Agency is eternal.'' The quasi-governmental Jewish Agency helps handle immigration and is responsible for Gilo, where 850 immigrants live. The protesters complained that ceilings and walls leaked when it rained and that central heating was turned off. They said the gas heaters they were given were dangerous, pointing to the case of an elderly Soviet woman who died last month after a gas heater explosion at Gilo. The immigrants, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also complained that families living on $400 a month had to pay $250 in rent at Gilo. Jewish Agency spokesman Gad Ben-Ari said the agency decided last week to close Gilo within a year because of housing quality problems. He said Gilo residents would be housed in rented apartments and public housing until a new absorption center was built in Jerusalem. Herzog and a group of dancing children meanwhile greeted 110 Soviet Jews who arrived at Ben-Gurion Airport near Tel Aviv from Budapest, Hungary. The children gave the immigrants roses and little Israeli flags. But Herzog warned the newcomers not everyhting in Israel would be as pleasant. Israel is settling many Soviet Jews in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, land it captured during the 1967 Middle East war. Arab nations oppose such a policy and say it will destroy chances for peace in the region. In Manama, Bahrain, the rulers of Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates conferred Sunday amid signs the Arab world was delaying a decision on convening a special summit on the issue. Emirates President Sheik Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan arrived Saturday from a visit to Egypt, where he advocated holding the summit, which was first called for by King Hussein of Jordan two weeks ago. The Gulf News Agency said that after his talks Sunday with the emir of Bahrain, Sheik Isa bin Salman Al Khalifa, the two discussed Arab issues in talks ``characterized by frankness and understanding.'' In Arab diplomatic terminology, ``frank'' indicates differences of opinion. Sources said the prospects of a summit and the subjects it would tackle, were major issues in the Bahrain talks. The two countries are grouped with Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Qatar and Oman in the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council alliance, which coordinates policy on regional, Arab and international issues. Aside from the statements by Sheik Zayed and a statement from Kuwait, the other alliance members have not picked up Jordan's summit call. Diplomatic sources said the alliance as a whole and other nations of the 22-member Arab League support the idea of a summit but want it convened only after clearing up inter-Arab differences. Foremost is the feud between Syria and Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Small Bombs Explode in Two Suburban-Atlanta Grocery Stores, None Hurt
DOC.TEXT: Two small bombs that exploded in suburban Atlanta grocery stores didn't cause any injuries, and apparently were unrelated to a series of bombings in the South last year that killed two, authorities said Sunday. No one was hurt in either of the bombings Saturday, though one bomb exploded while dozens of customers were still in the store, a Cub Foods market in this suburb 20 miles north of Atlanta. Both explosions followed telephoned threats to the stores. Similar calls to two other supermarkets prompted evacuations, but no bombs were found. ``The fuse train is all that detonated, so the effect of the bombs was really only that of a firecracker,'' FBI spokesman Pat Johnson said of the Cub Foods bomb. ``It didn't do much damage except to its packaging.'' Federal agents said Sunday they were still trying to determine the type of explosive used. They refused to comment on a possible motive or divulge other details of the investigation by local authorities and agents of the FBI and federal bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. Roswell's police chief, Jerry King, said the incidents didn't seem to be linked to unsolved mail bombings that killed a federal judge in Alabama and a lawyer in Savannah in December. At Cub Foods, witnesses said about 100 customers remained in the store when the bomb detonated in the paper products section. ``We got all the store personnel running registers and bagging to hurry up and get them out,'' said Royce Pugh, Cub Foods' assistant customer services manager, who took the warning call. ``I heard a boom and ran to look,'' said shopper Chuck Culpepper of Roswell. ``All I saw was a bunch of toilet paper in the aisle and debris from where the bomb shot. It sounded like a bunch of cherry bombs going off.'' At the Kroger, perishables manager Rhonda Bartlett said managers oversaw a quick evacuation. Groceries were left piled on checkout counters and in baskets, and the explosion came as shoppers and employees stood outside. ``We did not hear it, not at all,'' she said. ``We were just informed by the police that (the explosion) happened.'' Federal explosives and FBI agents and four explosives-sniffing dogs from the Atlanta police department searched all four stores. ``To my knowledge, nothing was found in the other two stores. They were both checked and both found to be clear,'' said ATF spokesman Tom Stokes. Stokes said that investigators were trying to identify the type of explosives used. He said there were no suspects so far. Agents took a package and pieces of cardboard, apparently covered with gunpowder residue, from the Kroger.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Students Support Death Sentence Against Author Rushdie
DOC.TEXT: Iranian media reports said thousands of students demonstrated Sunday to support the year-old death sentence against British author Salman Rushdie and also demanded that Briton Roger Cooper be executed. Cooper, a 53-year-old British businessman, has been held in prison on spying charges in Iran since Dec. 7, 1985. He lived in Iran for 20 years prior to his arrest. In London, the British Foreign Office said it ``deeply deplored'' the call for his execution. The late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, architect of Iran's Islamic revolution, issued a religious edict on Feb. 14, 1989, condemning Rushdie to death for what Khomeini said was the author's defaming of Islam in his novel ``The Satanic Verses.'' Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency, IRNA, said students issued a communique at the end of a march from Tehran University to the former British Embassy, calling for curbing trade relations with Britain and condemning Britain's recent deportation of nine Iranians. IRNA, monitored in Nicosia, said the statement demanded deportation of British journalists from Iran, although none is known to be stationed there, and that Cooper be put to death. Britain expelled the nine Iranians on Feb. 1 for what it said were national security reasons. It did not elaborate, but similar previous expulsions were linked to the Rushdie death decree. Rushdie, 42, has been in hiding in Britain under protective guard since Khomeini called for his head. Several Iranian leaders set a bounty of $5.2 million. Iranian news reports said demonstrators burned British and American flags while chanting, ``By the ruling of Khomeini, Salman Rushdie must be killed!'' ``Death to Britain!'' and ``Death to America!'' Rushdie, born in India of Moslem parents, is a British citizen. Iran cut ties with Britain last year when it supported Rushdie's right to publish ``The Satanic Verses.'' Sunday's reports said Moslem cleric Mohammad Ali Ansari, in charge of the institute publishing Khomeini's works, told the rally: ``Moslems are obliged to carry out the edict whatever the circumstances.'' Tehran radio quoted Ayatollah Mohammad Yazdi, head of the judiciary, as saying on Sunday that Moslems who possess the means to kill Rushdie but do not are sinners in the eyes of God. The broadcast quoted Yazdi as saying Khomeini's ruling that Rushdie be killed was ``unchangeable and irrevocable.''

DOC.HEAD: Snow Falls From California to Colorado, Rain Plagues Southeast
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell from Colorado to California on Sunday, while heavy rain forced dozens of families from their homes in Alabama. A winter storm warning was in effect until Monday for the southern mountains of Colorado. Snow fell elsewhere in Colorado and in parts of Utah, Nevada, Arizona and in California's Sierra Nevada range. Four inches of snow fell overnight near Las Vegas. Already soaked northwest Georgia could be hit by 2 to 3 inches more rain, the National Weather Service said. Five people have been killed in Alabama and Georgia since flooding started late last week. In northern Alabama, flooding along the Coosa, Black Warrior and Tallapoosa rivers forced dozens of families to evacuate. Rain also fell in South Carolina, Mississippi, southwest Tennessee, southwest Arkansas, Louisiana and eastern Texas. Temperatures around the nation at 3 pm EST ranged from 2 degrees in Warroad, Minn., to 86 degrees in Fort Myers, Fla. Temperatures reched record lows for the date in Alameda, Calif., 38 degrees, and Oakland, Calif., 37 degrees. The cold spot in the Lower 48 states was Massena, N.Y., with a morning low 19 degrees below zero.

DOC.HEAD: Thirteen-Year-old Sent to Prison for 38 Years After Lying About Age
DOC.TEXT: A 13-year-old Vietnamese immigrant who lied about his age was tried as an adult and sentenced to 38 years in prison four years ago for an armed robbery, a newspaper reported Sunday. Authorities are re-examining the case of Luan Van Hoang, who said he told police his name was Michael Nguyen and that he was 17 to avoid being returned to a California home for juvenile offenders, The Dallas Morning News said. The boy, who'd lived in the United States for four years and had limited knowledge of the legal system when arrested, said he believed Vietnamese friends who told him that lying about his age would result in probation. Dallas County authorities said they accepted Luan's story and tried him as an adult. But after reviewing records obtained by the Morning News that show Luan was a juvenile, District Attorney John Vance on Friday took steps to return the boy to Dallas to determine whether he should remain in prison. ``We're happy to know this,'' Vance said. ``If he is in fact a juvenile, he has no business being in our prison as an adult.'' Luan, now 17, is at the maximum-security Wynne prison in Huntsville with men, many of them twice his age, serving time for murder and other violent crimes. He said some of the men have tried to attack him sexually. ``I looked young,'' Luan said. ``If you are weak, they will try. They did try. They see I am different. I was scared. They tried to hurt me. I tried to protect myself.'' Texas prisons are limited to adult convicts and juvenile convicts 15 and older who are certified to stand trial as adults. Offenders under 15 are supposed to be tried in juvenile courts and, if found delinquent, sent to Texas Youth Commission centers. Luan's father, Tien Van Hoang, wrote state District Judge Jack Hampton, who presided over Luan's trial, that his son was underage. ``Nobody answer,'' said the Moreno Valley, Calif., man. ``Nobody write to me anything.'' Texas Department of Corrections officials know Luan only as Michael Nguyen. Department spokesman Charles Brown said Nguyen's file shows a birth date of Jan. 8, 1968, and identifies his father as Tien Van Hoang. ``There are errors all the time,'' Brown said. ``If there's an error, we're not opposed to correcting it. I don't think it's our error, though.'' Neither the boy nor his family has a copy of his birth certificate. ``When I escape from Vietnam by boat, everything was lost,'' said Tien, who was in the South Vietnamese Army and was imprisoned by the communists after the fall of Saigon in 1975. He escaped from prison. In 1982, he and his family sailed to the United States. According to U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service documents, Luan was born on Oct. 10, 1972, in South Vietnam. California public school records give the same date. ``It would appear to me ... that this person has been illegally sentenced and should be released if you can prove his age,'' said Ron Jackson, executive director of the Texas Youth Commission. Juvenile court records are confidential, but Luan said he was sent to a California halfway house for boys after arrests for joyriding and auto theft. He said he fled after serving eight months of a nine-month sentence. He hitched a ride to Texas, and joined a band of Vietnamese youths who police said were involved in robbing Asian refugees in the Dallas area. Luan admitted being present during the robbery of a man at gunpoint on Jan. 29, 1986. Police say they eventually linked Luan to several robberies in the area. Before his trial, Dallas County Assistant District Attorney Lana McDaniel offered Luan a plea bargain, but he refused. He was convicted, and sentenced to 38 years. Luan's girlfriend testified at the trial that the youth was 17. Ms. McDaniel said she relied upon the police determination of Luan's age. ``What am I supposed to do?'' she said. ``I can't investigate (the age of) every kid who tells us he's 17. He needs to learn not to lie when his life is on the line.''

DOC.HEAD: East German Gays Form Interest Group, Seek Reparations from Nazi Period
DOC.TEXT: East German homosexuals on Sunday formed their own interest group to fight for equal rights, including to adopt children and have partnerships with the legal force of marriage, news reports said. The Gay Association in East Germany, with headquarters in Leipzig, also will fight for reparations for persecution of homosexuals during the Nazi dictatorship, the official news agency ADN said. The Nazis persecuted homosexuals and put them in concentration camps along with Jews, communists, Gypsies and other groups. The Jews, who lost the most people in the camps, have received billions of dollars in reparations from the West German government. ADN did not say how many members the new group had.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Coffee Ship Turned Away From Fourth Port
DOC.TEXT: A ship carrying coffee from El Salvador was turned away from a fourth port Sunday because of protests spurred by the killing of six priests in that country. Dockworkers refused to unload 34 tons of coffee from the freighter Ciudad de Buenaventura, honoring a picket line of about 100 proponents of a boycott of Salvadoran coffee. Over ten days, the ship's cargo has been turned away from San Francisco; Vancouver, British Columbia; Seattle, and now the Port of Long Beach, 25 miles south of downtown Los Angeles. ``The fact that the ship was unsuccessful in landing on the West Coast sends a strong message to all shippers that they're going to have real trouble here,'' said Denise Bergez, spokeswoman for Neighbor to Neighbor, an activist group. ``It's going to cost them a lot of money to try to bring coffee to the West Coast.'' The San Francisco-based organization called for the boycott to protest U.S. support for the Salvadoran government, the death squads it accuses the government of supporting and the killings there of six Jesuit priests. Government troops have been implicated in the slayings. Coffee is one of El Salvador's principal exports, with about 60 percent of the harvest, worth $400 million, shipped to the United States each year. Union dock workers have announced their support for the boycott and some U.S. coffee companies agreed to stop shipping coffee to the West Coast. ``It's inconvenient for us, of course,'' Felipe Torres, manager of the company that owns the Ciudad de Buenaventura, told the Los Angeles Times in a report published Saturday. Speaking from his offices in Bogota, Colombia, Torres calculated the company's losses could reach $15,000 because of the protests. Demonstrators Sunday carried signs that said ``Boycott Salvadoran Death-Squad Coffee'' and chanting, ``Salvadoran coffee, send it back, don't unload one bloody sack.'' Longshoremen unloaded the ship's watermelons and other cargo, but refused to touch the Salvadoran coffee. The ship's next destination wasn't known.

DOC.HEAD: Pressured Government Defends Program of Austerity, Privatizations
DOC.TEXT: Ignoring pressure by labor, big business and political groups, the government reaffirmed its commitment to combat hyperinflation and recession by balancing the budget and selling public companies. ``There will be no change in the direction of the economic plan,'' Economy Minister Antonio Gonzalez said Sunday at a news conference broadcast nationwide after a two-hour Cabinet meeting chaired by President Carlos Menem. The meeting followed the slide of Argentina's currency by 28 percent against the U.S. dollar last week, drastic price mark-ups in stores and strikes by public workers that disrupted banks, federal courtrooms and oil fields. The Bankworkers Association vows to shut all five national banks, including the Central Bank, on Monday to protest plans to close 14 branches of the National Mortgage Bank and cut 1,200 jobs. University professors whose salaries were eroded by 79 percent inflation in January say they won't work beginning Monday until they get a pay hike the government says it cannot afford. That boycott could stall the start of classes next month. Gonzalez seemed to meet such opposition head on. The money-losing National Mortgage Bank will be restructured, he said, notwithstanding the opposition of employees who fear cuts in wages and benefits. Marginal fields operated by the state oil company YPF will be leased to foreign companies, Gonzalez said, a move that might yield $500 million in investment. Import tariffs will be lowered for selected food and pharmaceutical products whose prices have skyrocketed as local businessmen hiked prices with the dollar instead of inflation or actual costs, he said. Federal subsidies to provinces and private companies, such as tax benefits related to industrial development, will be suspended, he said, and public companies like the railroad will have to operate on the revenue they collect. The Menem government has been beset by economic woes since he took office last July. Inflation that month was 197 percent. By the end of the year, the gross domestic product had fallen by nearly 8 percent, and an estimated one of every five workers was under- or unemployed. Although endorsed by organized unions during the campaign, Menem implemented anti-labor policies of public service rate hikes, price increases ahead of wages, budget austerity. He freed controls on wages, prices and foreign exchange, and lowered import tariffs. The moves were designed to narrow the fiscal deficit that analysts put at a minimum 10 percent of the gross national product of approximately $70 billion. The 59-year-old attorney and former provincial governor said he had no choice. Foreign banks won't lend to Argentina, nor will Argentines except at extremely high rates of interest. And printing money converted a decade-long problem with inflation into hyperinflation that soared by 8,164 percent during the past 12 months. Policies of austerity have brought Menem criticism from leftist parties who campaigned for him, and from a growing number of dissidents within his own Peronist Party who believe the state should maintain its key role in the economy. The plan ``lacks confidence, credibility and efficiency,'' a leader of the opposition Civic Radical Union, Leopoldo Moreau, said Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Nearly 200 People Evacuated When Smoke Pours Into Jetliner's Cabin
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 200 people were evacuated from a TWA jetliner Sunday when the plane's cabin filled with thick, acrid smoke, authorities said. Three passengers suffered minor ankle injuries leaving the plane by its emergency escape chutes, said Fire Department spokesman Pat Marek. One of the passengers was taken to Daniel Freeman Memorial Hospital. The other two and a crew member who suffered smoke inhalation were treated at the scene, Marek said. The Lockheed L-1011, with 180 passengers and 12 crew members aboard, was being prepared for takeoff for John F. Kennedy Airport in New York when smoke poured into the cabin shortly before 4:30 p.m., prompting early reports that the craft was on fire, Marek said. ``Further investigation revealed there was no fire,'' he added. Workers found a broken fuel line, said Marek, who didn't know exactly what generated the smoke.

DOC.HEAD: Quake, Aftershock Hit Palm Springs Area
DOC.TEXT: A medium-sized earthquake and a smaller aftershock struck a remote area 20 miles southeast of this desert resort on Sunday, and no damage or injuries were reported. The first temblor struck at 7:52 a.m. and measured 4.2 on the Richter scale of ground motion, and was followed two minutes later by the aftershock measuring 3.1, said Hall Daily, a spokesman for the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. The Palm Springs Police Department received inquiries about the quake and aftershock, but no reports of trouble, said police assistant Lynette Detz, who said the department ``shook a little bit'' from the first quake. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 can cause moderate damage. Palm Springs is 110 miles east of Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: 10-Year-Old Boy Mauled By Dogs
DOC.TEXT: A 10-year-old boy was mauled by two dogs as he played outside his family's apartment, police said. Adam Bolt, who was rescued from the dogs by neighbors, rested at home after receiving 150 stitches in his neck and shoulders following the attack Saturday afternoon in this Orange County town 30 miles southeast of Los Angeles. The dogs, described by one witness as looking like huskies, were later cornered in a nearby oil field and shot to death by Placentia police officers. The dogs' owner hasn't been identified. Neighbor Mary Patuano said she started screaming when she saw the attack and another neighbor hit the animals with a broom until they ran off. ``Adam was on his stomach with one dog tearing at his shoulder like a shark. The other dog was pulling him in the other direction from his neck,'' Patuano said. Ms. Patuano said that one of the dogs had a rusty chain around his neck and that they looked like neglected guard dogs.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia's Havel Links Unified Germany to a Stronger Europe
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel said Sunday that the German desire to unite the two Germanys can help speed creation of a united Europe. But his foreign minister, Jiri Dienstbier, chastised the Christian Democratic party of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl for failing to state clearly that the present border between Germany and Poland will remain intact. Havel, the playwright-president who came to power in the surge of reforms that coursed over Eastern Europe, told a news conference that German unification must develop against the backdrop of a new Europe. ``I regard the desire of the Germans for unification not as an impediment, but as a driving force that can speed the development of the all-European home,'' he said. The president, accompanied by a team of senior ministers, is in Canada for a two-day visit. He is seeking assistance from Canada, mainly in the form of expertise to rebuild Czechoslovakia's economy and democratic institutions. He is also meeting with Czechoslovak-Canadians in Ottawa and Toronto. ``As we embark upon democracy, we have a lot to learn from other countries,'' Havel said. Czechoslovakia will hold its first free elections in 42 years in June. Havel was welcomed by Governor General Ray Hnatyshyn at Canadian Forces Base Uplands. He also met Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, leaders of federal opposition parties and former Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau. Havel will travel to Washington Tuesday to meet President Bush and address a joint session of Congress. In his remarks, Dienstbier said Poland's interests must be protected during German unification. Czechoslovakia and Poland share borders with what is now East Germany, and Poland has insisted that its interests be taken into account. Dienstbier said talks between the Germanys and the four World War II Allied powers _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France _ are a ``first step'' toward German unification. The talks were arranged last week in Ottawa during the Open Skies conference of the NATO and Warsaw Pact military alliances. ``Polish interests must be safeguarded. The western border of Poland is the only border about which no conclusive statement has been made on the German side,'' Dienstbier said. Kohl says any official position on the border issue should be taken up by a future parliament elected by a united Germany. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher has said the present borders will remain intact.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Commission Members Lay Wreath at Lockerbie Air Disaster Site
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's commission on aviation security and terrorism laid a wreath of red, white and blue flowers Sunday in memory of the victims of the Pan Am Flight 103 bombing. Commission Chairman Ann McLaughlin later told a news conference the likelihood of such a bombing occurring again was reduced by advances made in security following the disaster Dec. 21, 1988. The seven commissioners laid the wreath in an area of this small Scottish town where debris from the Boeing 747 destroyed municipal housing. They then went to the wind-swept Dryfesdale cemetery, where a permanent marble memorial has been dedicated to the 270 people killed when the airplane exploded _ all 259 on the plane and 11 on the ground. Mrs. McLaughlin placed the wreath next to a lacrosse stick left by a visiting team from Syracuse University. Many students enrolled in the university's study abroad program were among those killed. She told reporters later, ``I would suggest the terrorists are not winning, if security is good and getting better. There are still problems ... but the probablity of attack has been reduced since Lockerbie because of technical advances and human resource. ``Nothing spoke so loudly as the silence of some of the Pan Am impact sites here. This makes us ever more determined that the people responsible for murdering men, women and children at 31,000 feet above this community are brought to justice.'' During their four-day stay, commission members met with Transport Security Cecil Parkinson and security officials at London's Heathrow Airport. Flight 103 originated in Frankfurt, but passengers and baggage were transferred to a larger plane at Heathrow for the New York-bound flight. The commission also visited West Germany and France to consult airline, government and security officials. It will report in May to Bush on American policy on the terrorist threat to civil aircraft and make safety recommendations.

DOC.HEAD: Family, Friends Hold Celebration for Kephart
DOC.TEXT: An Army deserter who returned to the United States last month after nearly 30 years in East Germany was welcomed back at an open house Sunday. A motel in this city about five miles east of Omaha, Neb., played host to Arnold Kephart, 53, and some 75 relatives and friends, including a man from his old Army unit, the 503rd Transportation Company. ``This isn't a case involving a hero or military battles,'' said Kephart's attorney, James Martin Davis. ``Like the prodigal son who's been away for all these years, he is being welcomed back by his family and by his community.'' Kephart says he tried unsuccessfully to escape from East Germany, but didn't get out until after the Berlin Wall came down last year. Military police arrested him when he arrived in Omaha on Jan. 30 with his 12-year-old son, Frankie, shocking relatives who'd come to the airport to welcome him home. A week later, he was granted an other-than-honorable discharge. In 1960, Pvt. Kephart fled his Army unit in West Germany for East Germany because he was afraid he would be punished for crashing an Army truck. His letters didn't reach his family until about a year after he deserted, and letters that reached home were censored. Some relatives didn't believe Kephart was still alive, said a niece, Janice Dow of Logan, who was 10 months old when he disappeared. ``It always seemed like a big mystery to me,'' she said during the open house at the Frontier Motor Lodge. Kephart, who worked as a truck driver in the small southern city of Smalkalden, said Sunday he didn't want to run East Germany down. ``They are 40 to 50 years behind the times,'' he said. Clayton Schaner of Council Bluffs, who served in Kephart's company overseas, brought pictures of the old unit to the open house. He and Kephart discussed people and places they'd known. ``Remember we had the fence there and the Army depot, and people used to climb under the fence and sneak out?'' Schaner said. ``Ja, ja,'' Kephart replied in a German accent between drags on a cigarette. Kephart said his plans include exploring places he grew up in around Missouri, then getting a job and settling down in Council Bluffs for at least a year or two. Davis said there may be a television movie based on Kephart's life. Two production companies have made offers, and a third offer is expected, the attorney said. Kephart said many things have changed in the United States, shaking his head with wonder as he talked about the interstate highway system and the many types of cars on the road. Kephart, who is divorced, said his son will learn English and go to school. ``It will be hard for him,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Windy City Voting Said More Honest than Believed
DOC.TEXT: Political folklore has it that on Election Day in the Windy City, the dead miraculously cast ballots and party loyalists vote early and often. But the city's top election official said Sunday that the myth isn't true any more. Michael Hamblet, chairman of the Chicago Board of Election Commissioners, said a new board study shows Chicago elections appear to be about as honest as elections elsewhere. ``We always hear horror stories about ghost votes and people casting multiple ballots,'' Hamblet said. ``It is my belief that present-day Chicago elections are probably as clean or cleaner than any other jurisdiction.'' Hamblet says he remembers reading allegations by the U.S attorney in Chicago that about 100,000 people voted illegally in 1983, when Harold Washington was elected mayor. ``If that was true, it would be pretty startling,'' Hamblet said. ``I always beleived the figure was grossly inflated.'' To find out how many people were casting multiple ballots and the number of dead holding on to their voter registration cards, Hamblet authorized elections board investigators to do a computer study of voter registrations in the 1989 mayoral election. That election was won by Richard M. Daley, son of late Mayor Richard J. Daley. Hamblet said the board's computer, matching names, Social Security numbers and birth dates of voters, determined that 28,785 people were registered more than once _ meaning there could have been that many repeat voters. But when board personnel conducted a follow-up investigation to determine how many of those with duplicate registrations actually voted more than once, they could find only one repeat voter, Hamblet said. Board officials withheld the name of the repeat voter because they contended the voter cast the second ballot inadvertently. However, Chicago political consultant Don Rose says duplicate voting isn't the primary issue in Chicago elections. Assistance voting, where party precinct captains help point out selections for voters, should be of greater concern of the election board, Rose said. He also urged the board to make a concerted effort to purge the voter rolls of outdated names. ``What they (the board) does is conduct purges selectively,'' Rose said. ``The majority of purges take place in the minority community, to some extent with good reason because mobility there is higher. But also because it is easier.'' Hamblet defended the board. ``I don't think there is evidence that we aren't being impartial,'' he said. ``From our standpoint we are doing everything we can to make it a fair and impartial purge.'' Hamblet said that through a variety of means of checking, the board usually eliminates about 50,000 to 100,000 people from the voter rolls each election. Despite his reservations about the board's efforts, Rose agrees with Hamblet that Chicago's elections are more honest than in the past.

DOC.HEAD: Excavators Dig Up Marble Statue in Pompeii
DOC.TEXT: Archaeologists unearthed a small marble statue buried in the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 A.D., the first such find in 13 years, newspapers reported Sunday. The statue, which depicts a baby boy riding a dolphin, was found Saturday in the House of the Casti Amanti, near the center of the abandoned city, Il Mattino of Naples and other papers reprted. Archaeologists said the statue was apparently to be used to decorate a fountain in the house, but that Vesuvius erupted before workers had a chance to set it in place. Experts said traces of paint coloring the hair blond and eyebrows black made the find even more valuable. They believe the House of Casti Amanti was owned by a baker, who lived on one side and kept a shop on the other. The last statue to be found in Pompeii was a bronze dug up in 1977.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Urges West Maintain Strong Defenses
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Sunday the West needs to maintain strong military defenses, despite broad Soviet troop cuts, because ``you never know where a new threat might come from.'' In a speech to the Board of Deputies of British Jews, she also said any German unification agreement must respect existing European borders. Mrs. Thatcher said, ``Hopefully there will be an opportunity to make some reductions in our forces as part of balanced reductions by both NATO and the Warsaw Pact. ``But we shall not do anything which will put our defense and our security at risk, nor weaken our capability to undertake out-of-area tasks, and that means that we shall continue to need our independent nuclear deterrent as well as strong and well-equipped conventional forces.'' The United States and Soviet Union agreed this month to deep troop cuts in Central Europe, and Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia are negotiating troop cuts with Moscow. But Mrs. Thatcher said the Soviet Union will still have ``vast military capabilities,'' and that the West should not become complacent and undermine or dismantle institutions such as NATO. ``If we had had something equivalent to NATO in the 1930s, we should never have had a Second World War. We shall always have to keep adequate defenses because you never know where a new threat might come from,'' she said. ``One has to bear in mind that 12 countries outside NATO and the Warsaw Pact already have ballistic missiles, and many more ... could be in a position to acquire nuclear weapons by the end of the century.'' She said any agreement on German unification must respect existing borders in Europe and the rights of the four Allied powers, Britain, France, the United States and the Soviet Union. She said she hoped a united Germany would remain part of NATO, with U.S. troops stationed there, ``with some special arrangements for East Germany to meet the Soviet Union's security concerns. Indeed, it would be quite reasonable for some Soviet troops to remain there at least for a transitional period.'' The Soviet Union says it would seek troop reductions in a unified Germany as well as withdrawal from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Mrs. Thatcher said Britain support's Poland's wish to have its western border with Germany guaranteed by a treaty. No peace treaty was signed at the end of World War II, so Poland has no formal guarantees of its border. Poland, which was overrun by Nazi Germany, wants a role in planned talks among the four Allies and East and West Germany so it can protect its borders. Mrs. Thatcher also pledged to continue campaigning for Jews wrongly imprisoned in the Soviet Union, but warned it would be unjust if Israel settled Soviet emigrants in the occupied territories. She renewed her appeal to Israel to talk to Palestinians about elections in the occupied territories.

DOC.HEAD: Music Obscenity Conviction Returns To Court Monday
DOC.TEXT: The obscenity conviction of a record store owner involving a rap music recording and believed to be the first of its kind in the nation is the subject of a new trial opening Monday. Tommy Hammond, who was convicted in 1988 of violating this city's obscenity ordinance by selling the rap group 2 Live Crew's ``Move Somethin,''' will be represented by the Civil Liberties Union of Alabama at his Tallapoosa County Circuit Court trial. ``Should this conviction stand, it will open the doors for similar prosecutions around the state,'' the organization said in a statement last week. Hammond's conviction marked the first time music was found to be legally obscene in the United States, the American Civil Liberties Union and music industry officials have said. He was arrested after a woman complained to police about her son obtaining a copy of the ``Move Somethin''' cassette at Hammond's record shop in this city of about 14,000 people about 40 miles northeast of Montgomery. Hammond was convicted in municipal court and fined $500. Under Alabama law, any conviction before a Municipal Court judge must receive a jury trial at the circuit court level before it can be appealed. Hammond's Montgomery attorneys, Robert Segall and Elizabeth Johnson, contend he is a victim of discriminatory prosecution. Segall said another Alexander City record store sold the same recording after Hammond did, but wasn't prosecuted. Police told the judge the other record store owner wasn't arrested because he refused to sell the recording to a police informant. Ms. Johnson said Sunday night that the case also raises the issue of free speech, which is guaranteed under the First Amendment of the U.S. Constitution. ``The question is whether or not he can sell the tapes to an adult,'' she said. ``Children do not enter into this case at all.'' An attorney for the city, Daniel Brown, said last year that 2 Live Crew violated Alexander City's obscenity laws because the group's lyrics provide detailed descriptions of perverse sexual acts and sadomasochism. Ms. Johnson disagreed at the time, saying ``profanity and offensive music are not what obscenity is all about. You may be offended by it, but that doesn't make it obscene.'' The group records under the Miami-based Luke Skywalker label, which paid half of Hammond's legal fees in the first round of the legal fight. Label spokeswoman Debbie Bennett has said the recording's sexually explicit language is intended as humor and is far from being obscene.

DOC.HEAD: Two Arrested in Maryland in Killing of Florida Deputy
DOC.TEXT: Two men wanted in the slaying of a Florida sheriff's deputy and the wounding of another during a robbery were arrested at a toll plaza Sunday afternoon, Maryland State Police said. Lancelot Urisley Armstrong, 26, of Lauderhill, Fla., and Wayne Allen Coleman, 20, of Miami, surrendered peacefully after state police cars converged on them at the toll booth on Interstate 95 north of Baltimore, said Sgt. Bruce Speck. Armstrong and Coleman were charged as fugitives and held pending bond review before a District Court commissioner, according to authorities. Armstrong and Coleman were being sought in connection with the killing of Broward County, Fla., Deputy John Greeney III. He and his partner were shot as they responded to a silent holdup alarm at a Church's Fried Chicken outlet in Fort Lauderdale on Saturday. When the deputies pulled into the restaurant parking lot, ``two armed men came out and opened fire on them,'' said sheriff's spokesman George Crolius. ``One of them had a semiautomatic weapon, we believe.'' Greeney, 47, had been a deputy for 3{ years, after a career as a military police officer, said sheriff's spokesman Al Gordon. Deputy Robert Sallustio, 25, hit in the back, arm and leg, was listed in fair and stable condition at Broward General Medical Center, Gordon said. No customers were in the restaurant, but one and possibly two employees were inside.

DOC.HEAD: Minor Quake in South Carolina
DOC.TEXT: An small earthquake shook a rural area early Sunday, and there were no reports of damage. The tremor registered 2.3 on the Richter scale of ground motion, said Joyce Bagwell, director of the Earthquake Education Center at Baptist College at Charleston. ``About 7:24 a.m. some Summerville residents were awakened by a slight explosive sound and a rumbling. I felt it myself,'' Ms. Bagwell said. ``Some people at the college said it felt like a train rumbling through just slightly.'' It was felt in an area between Summerville and Middleton Place, some 20 miles north of Charleston, she said. Since the beginning of the year, four earthquakes have shaken lower South Carolina, Mrs. Bagwell said. Only two were strong enough to be felt, she said. Earthquakes in the Summerville and North Charleston areas aren't uncommon, she said. A quake of magnitude 3.5 _ more than 10 times the strength of the Carolina temblor _ is considered capable of causing slight damage in the immediate area.

DOC.HEAD: End-All Tries to Make Money Through the Nose
DOC.TEXT: One day the scent wafting through End-All Products Co. might be a cross between baby powder and citrus. On another day, the tiny western Maryland factory might smell like bubble gum, the scent of a deodorizer sold to freshen the holding tanks of portable toilets from coast to coast. ``We have the mission of making things smell nice,'' company president Phil Gamerman said as he waved vials of portable toilet fragrances under his nose. ``If it's freshly cleaned and serviced, the toilet is likely to smell like bubble gum or cherries,'' he said. ``Why? It's a total mystery to me. It's the tradition in that industry. They work. They're just nice, strong scents that cover.'' Ron Gillette, managing editor of the monthly magazine Sanitary Maintenance, said the more than $12 billion sanitary supply distribution and wholesale industry is expanding steadily. ``The scents themselves have caught up with the public's desire. It's no longer the killer pine or ammonia smell. Now, we have have orange, cherry _ they don't overpower us,'' he said. In addition to the liquid deodorizing products, End-All makes half-dollar-sized discs of heavy blotter paper treated with potent drops of various fragrances. Diaper services put the non-toxic sachets in bundles of clean diapers. Businesses buy them for laundry rooms, toilets and laboratory incubators where smelly cultures grow. Besides the cherry, bubblegum and citrus-baby powder scents, the sachets are made to smell like lemons or candy cinammon hearts. The company is trying to market the pleasant-smelling discs to janitorial services that clean offices. They could be used in broom closets, trash cans, offices, bathrooms or wherever the air is musty or stale. ``Also, with a slight change in packaging, we're going to put sticky patches on the backs so you can slap them under a sink or anywhere,'' Gamerman said. In late 1985, Gamerman, a 45-year-old Baltimore native trained in psychotherapy, took over part of the deodorizer business from his former partner, who peddles pet products and deodorizers for pets. In his first full year of business, End-All posted $35,000 in sales. Last year, sales totaled $233,000. ``There's not a whole lot of financial reward at this point,'' Gamerman said, adding that his goal is to pass $1 million in annual sales within two years. ``We're operating profitably, but we are putting everything back into the business as fast as we make it.'' Besides Gamerman, End-All employs seven others _ three full-time and two part-time production workers, a salesman and Teresa Smith, office manager. ``The first week I went home from work with headaches. My husband would say `You smell like ... I don't know what you smell like,''' Smith said. ``Now, I don't even notice it.'' Winter is a slow time for End-All. ``Things don't smell so much in the wintertime,'' Gamerman said. ``We really work hard on the telephone in Florida and southern California.'' To offset the slowdown, Gamerman developed the deodorizing discs with the sticky backs and is working on a line of janitorial cleaning supplies for nationwide distribution. ``I look for niche markets,'' he said. ``I look for unique twists on a product.'' He also is working on a new fragrance spray or sachet that could be put inside used luxury cars at car dealerships. ``We're not talking about a cheap, industrial-type fragrance. We're talking about a fine fragrance,'' he said. ``This is going to make them smell like Ferraris or Rolls-Royces.''

DOC.HEAD: Governing Party Keeps Majority, But Loses Seats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 28 grfs to ADD comments from Socialist and Komeito party officials on results, details on Recruit-linked candidates who won and lost. Pickup 25th pvs, `Takashi Aida...; Final results not expected before midnight EST. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TOK24
DOC.TEXT:
Japan's conservative governing party held on to its 34-year-old majority in Parliament's powerful lower house Sunday, but scandals and an unpopular tax may have cost it nearly three dozen seats in the closely watched election. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu called the preliminary results ``a form of purification'' for his troubled Liberal Democratic Party. The secretary-general of the main opposition Socialist Party, Tsuruo Yamaguchi, disagreed: ``Simply being elected does not mean one is absolved.'' The Socialists made strong gains. The political outlook was clouded because the opposition holds a majority in Parliament's upper house, making it difficult to pass major legislation or deal with trade problems with the United States. The Liberal Democrats needed at least 257 seats to maintain control of the 512-seat lower house, which chooses the prime minister and can pass a budget without assent of the upper house. With 80 percent of the 66 million ballots counted late Sunday, election officials declared the Liberal Democrats had won 240 seats, compared with 114 for the Socialists. The Clean Government Party had 31 seats, the Communist Party 13, the Democratic Socialist Party 12, the United Social Democratic Party three, and 18 independents were elected. Votes for the remaining 81 seats were to be counted Monday. Kyodo News Service predicted 271 seats for the Liberal Democrats, enough to control all standing committees in the house but far short of the 295 they held after the last election in June 1986. ``I think we have defended our majority at least,'' said Ichiro Ozawa, secretary-general of the party, while conceding the loss of rural seats where farmers reacted angrily to increased imports of agricultural products. About 73 percent of the 90.5 million eligible voters _ a high turnout _ cast ballots. The election was seen as a test of whether the Liberal Democrats had recovered from a disastrous year of scandals and implementation of an unpopular 3 percent sales tax. Two conservative prime ministers resigned in quick succession last year amid sex and money scandals, and the Socialists' popular chairwoman, Takako Doi, 61, seemed to have a chance to tilt Japan to the left. But the conservative Japanese voters rejected that bold step, though the Socialists enhanced their standing as the No. 1 opposition party. They had 83 seats in the outgoing house. Ms. Doi refused to concede defeat or comment in detail before the final count. ``I'd like to wait until the results are in, in hope of good news,'' she said. Yamaguchi, the Socialist secretary-general, attributed the Liberal Democrats' success to ``support from big business and large contributions from corporations.'' At least a dozen Liberal Democrats won re-election despite being linked to last year's so-called Recruit scandal, in which influential politicians profited from cut-rate stock offered by the Recruit Co. conglomerate in return for political favors. Kaifu, 59, called the results a ``significant verdict of the people.'' ``It is a form of purification,'' he said. Koshiro Ishida, chairman of the Komeito (Clean Government Party), denounced the results, saying, ``There has been no `purification.' I'd like to know how the Liberal Democrats plan to take responsibility (for corrupt politics).'' The post-election period will be crammed with foreign policy issues as well as political work to deal with the legislative roadblocks facing the government. U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is arriving Tuesday to ask Japan to increase its payments supporting the 50,000 U.S. troops based here. On Thursday, U.S.-Japan negotiations resume to seek ways to cut deeply into Japan's $49 billion trade surplus with the United States. Those re-elected included former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, 65, who resigned last year after admitting that he accepted huge donations from the Recruit Co.; and Takeshita's replacement, Sousuke Uno, 67, who lasted only two months as prime minister. A former geisha said Uno had paid her to be his mistress, and he resigned after the Liberal Democrats lost badly in the upper house election. Another winner was former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, 72, who resigned from the party in disgrace last year. He ran as an independent. ``A general election is a judgment by the people, and I passed,'' said Nakasone. The Recruit scandal erupted after he left office in 1987, but the stocks-for-favors transactions took place while he was prime minister, and he was forced to testify to Parliament about his links to the Recruit Co. Nakasone's re-election may permit him to return to the party and greater behind-the-scenes influence. Former Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe, 65, seen as a likely successor to Kaifu, also won re-election despite Recruit links that forced him to step down as party secretary general, a post that often is a stepping stone to the prime minister's office. The only Recruit-linked candidate who lost was Kunio Takaishi, a former vice minister of education who is under indictment for bribery. Late Sunday, police arrested one of his private secretaries on charges of handing out cash to voters. Voters' commends indicated a wariness of handing power to the Socialists.
Takashi Aida, 40 and self-employed, said he voted for the Socialists in last summer's election for the less powerful upper house, but voted for a Liberal Democrat on Sunday. ``It is different this time because we are voting for the lower house. ... Opposition parties wouldn't be able to handle politics in the lower house,'' he said. A 31-year-old doctor said he was no Liberal Democratic Party supporter, ``but I just had to choose (them) because nobody else is capable.''

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Agrees to Transfer Mortgage-backed Securities Portfolio to Goldman
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has agreed to transfer its portfolio of mortgage-backed securities to Goldman, Sachs & Co., the two investment banks announced. The transfer was encouraged and facilitated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the two firms said. A spokesman for Drexel, whose parent company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last week, said he did not know if Goldman Sachs would pay anything for the portfolio. The two firms said Drexel's holdings of securities for current settlement was modest in size and its holdings for future settlement was a diversified, hedged portfolio of government agency and mortgage-backed securities. The transfer is subject to the consent of counterparties who had entered into trades with Drexel, the firms said. They added that they hope to complete the transfer by Thursday. Drexel has been liquidating its securities holdings since its bankruptcy filing and has been working to transfer customer accounts to other brokerages. The firm laid off the bulk of its 5,300 employees on Friday and is closing down rapidly following the failure of its parent holding company to obtain financing early last week.
